name: I Ching HD Meta-Categories: Three Lenses for Viewing the 64 Hexagrams
description: This interpretation maps the 64 I Ching hexagrams to Human Design 'gates'—a synthesis channeled by Ra Uru Hu in 1987 after an eight-day encounter with 'the Voice' on Ibiza. The system is only about 30 years old, which means we're still discovering what it actually describes, if anything beyond symbolic vocabulary. Ra claimed the Voice transmitted a complete system mapping I Ching hexagrams around an astrological wheel in specific relationships to planetary positions. Whether this represents genuine cosmic blueprints, a playful reconfiguration of ancient symbolic systems, or simply altered consciousness creating coherent pattern, remains genuinely open. What's documented: many people find the 'types' (Manifestor, Generator, Projector, Reflector, Manifesting Generator) and gate activations offer useful language for recognizing their patterns. The identity game is always dangerous, especially when systems are lifted from their traditional contexts and sold as objective truth. Over-identification with any typology can become a cage. That said, personally discovering I was supposedly a 'Projector' rather than trying to operate like a 'Generator' released me from exhausting patterns—it gave me permission to develop recursive.eco intimately rather than forcing myself into productivity modes that never fit. That release alone makes the system worth studying, even if it's 'just' a useful fiction. Whether it serves you is yours to discover. The gates maintain exact I Ching numbering (Gate 1 = Hexagram 1, etc.) and are arranged around the Rave Mandala wheel in Fu Xi sequence. Each gate occupies approximately 5.625 degrees, with some gates spanning two zodiac signs. Use this as contemplative material for self-reflection and pattern recognition, not as fixed identity or limitation. Hold it lightly. Fork it freely.

sections.Image: Heaven's movement is full of power. Thus the superior one makes themselves strong and untiring.
sections.Line 1: Hidden creative power not yet expressed. Foundation building. Modesty in creative expression—waiting for the right timing before revealing your direction.
sections.Line 2: Emerging into view. Creative power begins to manifest. Natural creative expression that doesn't force itself but emerges when recognized.
sections.Line 3: Active all day, vigilant at night. Creative work requires sustained attention. Dedicated creativity, but watch for burnout from over-identifying with your expression.
sections.Line 4: Wavering flight, flexibility in expression. Exploring different creative directions without commitment—this is healthy experimentation.
sections.Line 5: Flying dragon in the heavens—creative power at its peak. Full, mature creative expression that influences the collective.
sections.Line 6: Arrogant dragon will have cause to repent. Over-identification with your creativity leads to rigidity. Stay humble.
sections.Judgment: The Creative works through sublime success, furthering through perseverance. What begins as pure potential becomes manifest through sustained direction.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 1 represents the archetypal force of creative self-expression and unique direction. This is the impulse to express something that only you can bring into the world. In the bodygraph, it sits in the G Center (Identity) and speaks to knowing your creative direction in life, your unique contribution, your authentic voice. When this gate is defined (activated by planets at birth), there may be a consistent pull toward expressing individuality and showing others new directions or possibilities. When undefined, there's more flexibility about creative direction, sampling different paths without fixed commitment. The classical I Ching interpretation emphasizes pure creative power—heaven doubled—suggesting relentless forward motion and the ability to initiate cycles. In Human Design's reinterpretation, this becomes personal creative authority rather than cosmic force. The energy here is about demonstrating that each person has a unique direction to offer, modeling individuality without demanding that others follow. The shadow appears when creativity is forced on demand, when expression becomes performative rather than authentic, or when the need to be unique overrides genuine self-knowing. The gift is natural self-expression that inspires without coercion—you show what's possible simply by being yourself creatively. Practically, this gate often manifests as people looking to you for creative direction, not because you're trying to lead but because your authentic expression naturally reveals new possibilities. This is symbolic language for contemplating your relationship to creative individuality, not a fixed mandate about who you must be.

sections.Image: The earth's condition is receptive devotion. Thus the superior one carries all things with spacious virtue.
sections.Line 1: Treading on hoarfrost, solid ice ahead. Early intuitive knowing—trust the small signs before direction becomes obvious.
sections.Line 2: Straight, square, great. No practice needed—natural receptivity. Your knowing is reliable without effort when you trust it.
sections.Line 3: Hidden lines keep persevering. Sometimes your direction is private—not all knowing needs to be shared immediately.
sections.Line 4: Tied-up sack—no blame, no praise. Restraint in sharing your direction. Not all inner knowing is for public consumption.
sections.Line 5: Yellow lower garment brings supreme fortune. Grounded, centered receptivity. Your direction serves others when it comes from calm presence.
sections.Line 6: Dragons fight in the meadow. Conflict between forcing direction and receiving it. Choose receptivity over ego.
sections.Judgment: The Receptive brings supreme success through the perseverance of a mare. Receptivity is not passive—it's responsive, intuitive, and profoundly generative.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 2 represents receptive knowing of direction—the counterpart to Gate 1's creative expression. This is your connection to intuitive guidance about where you're meant to go, your internal GPS for life direction. When defined, there's consistent access to inner knowing about direction. When undefined, direction is sampled from others and learned through experience. The classical I Ching's pure receptivity—earth doubled—emphasizes yielding strength, the power of allowing rather than forcing. In Human Design's framework, this becomes your capacity to receive direction from something larger than ego: intuition, higher self, synchronicity, whatever language fits your worldview. The key distinction is that this isn't passive waiting; it's responsive receptivity. You know where you're going by staying open to intuitive hits, dreams, gut feelings, or simply allowing the knowing to emerge rather than manufacturing it mentally. The shadow is forcing direction through willpower when genuine inner knowing isn't present, or spiritual bypassing where you avoid responsibility by waiting for the universe to tell you everything. The gift is trusting receptive knowing even when it doesn't make logical sense, even when you can't explain why you're going this direction. Practically, this gate often manifests as finding that your best direction comes when you stop trying to figure it out mentally and just allow the knowing to surface. Whether this reflects actual energetic wiring or is simply a useful metaphor for trusting intuition over analysis is an open question. The archetypal language can be valuable for contemplation regardless.

sections.Image: Thunder and water mix: difficulty at the beginning. The superior one brings order out of chaos.
sections.Line 1: Hesitation and hindrance. Waiting for the right moment to initiate—don't force mutation prematurely.
sections.Line 2: Difficulties pile up. Multiple new beginnings at once can be overwhelming. Focus and persevere with support.
sections.Line 3: Hunting without a guide. Innovation without direction leads to confusion. Seek guidance or collaborate.
sections.Line 4: Seeking help brings good fortune. Mutation is more successful when you involve others in the process.
sections.Line 5: Difficulties in blessing others. Your innovations may not be immediately appreciated—trust the process.
sections.Line 6: Horse and wagon part—tears flow. Sometimes new directions require leaving old forms behind. Grieve and continue.
sections.Judgment: Initial difficulty brings supreme success through perseverance. Do not undertake anything new lightly, but appointing helpers brings good fortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 3 in the Sacral Center represents mutation or ordering through chaos—the energy of innovation through experimentation. This is about starting new things even when you don't have all the pieces figured out, trusting that order will emerge from the initial chaos. The classical hexagram speaks to the difficulty inherent in all beginnings: thunder and water mixing creates turbulence before clarity. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes your relationship to change, novelty, and the messy process of bringing new things into form. If defined, there's consistent access to innovative energy, though it may feel chaotic or uncertain. You can handle disorder because you trust that patterns will emerge. If undefined, innovation comes in bursts or is learned from others. The shadow is forcing change just for change's sake, getting addicted to chaos, or getting stuck in perpetual experimentation without bringing things to completion. The gift is trusting the mutation process—knowing that difficulty at the beginning doesn't mean you're on the wrong path, it just means you're actually creating something new rather than repeating the known. Order emerges through the experimental process, not before it. Practically, this gate often manifests as being pulled toward experimental approaches, struggling with traditional orderly systems, and excelling when given permission to try unusual solutions. Whether this reflects actual energetic design or is simply a useful lens for understanding different approaches to innovation and change remains contemplative territory. The archetypal language serves self-reflection.

sections.Image: A spring flows from the base of the mountain: the image of youth. The superior one develops character through thorough actions.
sections.Line 1: To discipline the fool brings humiliation. Mental clarity requires experience, not force. Allow answers to emerge.
sections.Line 2: To bear with fools with kindness brings good fortune. Patience with your own and others' learning process.
sections.Line 3: Don't be like a girl who loses herself for metal and gold. Don't abandon your mental process for superficial answers.
sections.Line 4: Entangled folly brings humiliation. Getting lost in your own mental formulas without reality-testing.
sections.Line 5: Childlike folly brings good fortune. Beginner's mind—approaching problems with openness rather than fixed formulas.
sections.Line 6: Punishing folly doesn't further. Forcing mental clarity or judging confusion doesn't help. Allow understanding to unfold.
sections.Judgment: Success comes not from seeking the oracle, but from the oracle seeking you. The first time brings an answer; repeating questions shows lack of respect.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 4 in the Ajna Center represents the process of forming mental formulas, answers, and logical frameworks. This is about your relationship to mental certainty and conceptual organization. In the classical I Ching, 'youthful folly' refers to the inexperienced mind that asks questions without yet understanding how to evaluate answers. In Human Design's reinterpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent access to mental clarity and formulization. If defined, there's a reliable way of arriving at conclusions and creating frameworks. You might be the person others come to for answers. If undefined, thinking is more fluid and open to multiple perspectives without needing certainty. The classical wisdom here is about respecting the process of learning: don't ask the same question repeatedly expecting different answers. Form your answer, test it, revise it based on results. The shadow is either getting stuck in rigid mental formulas ('this IS the answer') or drowning in uncertainty because you can't commit to any framework. The gift is mental clarity that serves others—not because your formulas are objectively correct, but because they're coherent enough to be useful. Your frameworks help organize complexity into workable patterns. Practically, this gate often manifests as naturally systematizing information, creating frameworks, or developing formulas (mathematical, philosophical, practical) that help make sense of complex data. Remember that this speaks to mental processing style, not intelligence or correctness. Different ways of thinking have different gifts.

sections.Image: Clouds rise up to heaven: the image of waiting. The superior one eats, drinks, and remains serene.
sections.Line 1: Waiting in the meadow. Patience in familiar territory. Your natural rhythms are reliable when you honor them.
sections.Line 2: Waiting on the sand—gossip emerges. Disruptions to your rhythm may cause irritability. Stay grounded.
sections.Line 3: Waiting in mud invites danger. Fighting against your natural rhythms leads to depletion.
sections.Line 4: Waiting in blood—get out of the pit. Crisis forces adaptation. Fixed rhythms must sometimes flex.
sections.Line 5: Waiting at meat and drink. Trust that nourishment comes when you honor your timing.
sections.Line 6: Fall into the pit—unexpected guests arrive. Disruption of rhythms can bring unexpected gifts if you remain open.
sections.Judgment: Waiting with confidence brings supreme success. Perseverance furthers. Crossing the great water is favorable.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 5 in the Sacral Center represents fixed rhythms and natural patterns of consistency. This is about your relationship to habit, routine, and regular patterns in life. The classical I Ching hexagram emphasizes waiting with confidence—not anxious waiting, but patient trust that the right timing will emerge. Water above heaven suggests nourishment that will come in its natural time. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes about your body's natural rhythms: sleep, hunger, work cycles, creative flow. If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's a consistent daily rhythm that works well—disrupting it causes depletion. You might naturally wake at the same time, need meals at regular intervals, or have predictable energy patterns. If undefined, there's more flexibility with timing and rhythms, adapting easily to changing schedules. The shadow is rigidity—forcing yourself or others to conform to a fixed pattern even when life requires flexibility. Or conversely, fighting against your natural rhythms because they seem boring or limiting. The gift is honoring consistent patterns without making them an identity or prison. You can have a morning routine and still adapt when needed. The structure serves you; you don't serve the structure. Practically, this gate often manifests as thriving with regular schedules and predictability. Travel, irregular hours, or chaos might be more depleting than for others. Whether this reflects actual energetic wiring or is a useful framework for understanding individual differences in need for consistency versus variety remains an open question for contemplation.

sections.Image: Heaven and water move in opposite directions: the image of conflict. The superior one carefully considers the beginning when undertaking affairs.
sections.Line 1: Don't perpetuate conflict. Not all emotional friction needs to be pursued. Let small tensions dissolve.
sections.Line 2: Withdrawing from conflict brings no blame. Sometimes the best response to friction is stepping back.
sections.Line 3: Feed on ancient virtue—danger but good fortune in the end. Draw on past emotional wisdom when navigating current friction.
sections.Line 4: Cannot carry on the conflict—returning brings good fortune. Know when to release emotional negotiation and accept difference.
sections.Line 5: Going to court brings supreme good fortune. Formal negotiation of emotional friction (therapy, mediation) can be healing.
sections.Line 6: Even if granted a belt, it will be taken away three times before morning. Winning emotional conflicts doesn't lead to lasting intimacy.
sections.Judgment: Conflict requires seeking the middle way. Going to the source brings clarity, but pushing forward brings misfortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 6 in the Solar Plexus Center represents friction in intimacy—the necessary negotiation that happens when two people (or parts of yourself) have different emotional truths. This isn't conflict for conflict's sake, but the honest friction required to find authentic alignment. The classical hexagram shows heaven and water moving in opposite directions, suggesting inherent tension. In Human Design's reading, this becomes about emotional negotiation: how do you handle friction in intimate relationships? If defined in your emotional solar plexus, there's consistent energy for working through emotional friction. You might actually be comfortable with conflict as a doorway to deeper intimacy. If undefined, you might avoid friction or feel overwhelmed by emotional tension. The shadow is either forcing conflict unnecessarily (friction addiction) or suppressing genuine friction and pretending everything is fine. Neither extreme serves intimacy. The gift is recognizing that friction is how intimate systems find authentic alignment—not through pretending to agree, but through honest negotiation of different truths. You're willing to experience the discomfort of disagreement because you trust it leads somewhere real. Practically, this gate often manifests as close relationships involving substantial honest conflict. You might say 'we fight a lot but we're really close' and mean it positively. The friction builds intimacy rather than destroying it. The challenge is distinguishing productive friction (leading to deeper understanding) from destructive conflict (just causing harm). This is contemplative territory for exploring your relationship to emotional honesty in intimacy.

sections.Image: Water in the earth: the army's image. The superior one increases their masses by generous treatment of the people.
sections.Line 1: Army marches forth in order—if not orderly, misfortune. Leadership requires clear internal structure before influencing others.
sections.Line 2: In the midst of the army—good fortune, no blame. Leading from within the group rather than above it.
sections.Line 3: Army carries corpses—misfortune. Taking on others' emotional baggage while leading drains your direction.
sections.Line 4: Army retreats—no blame. Sometimes the right leadership move is withdrawal or redirection.
sections.Line 5: Field has game—advantage in capturing it. Clear purpose makes your leadership effective and beneficial.
sections.Line 6: Great prince gives commands. Mature leadership that empowers others rather than controlling them.
sections.Judgment: The army needs perseverance and a strong leader. Good fortune with no blame.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 7 in the G Center represents your role in leading or influencing others. The classical I Ching uses military metaphor: an army requires clear direction and responsible leadership. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes about your identity in relation to others—what role do you naturally play in collective settings? Are you a director, a guide, a democratic leader, or someone who prefers not to lead at all? If this gate is defined, there's consistent energy for taking a role in influencing or directing others. People might naturally look to you for guidance or expect you to take charge. If undefined, you're more flexible about roles and might not feel called to lead. The shadow is either forcing yourself into leadership when it's not your natural expression, or abdicating all responsibility for influence when you actually do have something valuable to contribute. The gift is recognizing that leadership isn't about domination; it's about clear direction that serves the collective. You know your role, you play it well, and you don't inflate or deflate its importance. You lead when appropriate and follow when appropriate, without making either an identity. Practically, this gate often manifests as finding yourself in guiding roles—not necessarily formal authority, but informal influence. You're the friend everyone comes to for direction, the colleague who naturally organizes projects, the family member who provides orientation. This is contemplative territory for exploring your relationship to influence and collective roles.

sections.Image: Water flows over earth: the image of holding together. Ancient kings established states and maintained connection with feudal lords.
sections.Line 1: Hold to them with truth—no blame. Your contribution begins with authenticity, not performance.
sections.Line 2: Hold to them from within—perseverance brings good fortune. Genuine self-expression, not manufactured image.
sections.Line 3: Hold to those who are not the right people. Trying to model for an audience that doesn't resonate with your authenticity.
sections.Line 4: Hold to them openly—perseverance brings good fortune. Public modeling of your authentic way.
sections.Line 5: Manifestation of holding together—the king uses beaters on three sides only. Your contribution attracts naturally; you don't chase an audience.
sections.Line 6: Holding together brings no head—misfortune. Contribution without authentic center becomes performative and draining.
sections.Judgment: Holding together brings good fortune. Seek the oracle again to know if you have constancy and perseverance. Then no blame.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 8 in the Throat Center represents contribution through authentic self-expression and modeling. This is about whether you make your unique contribution by demonstrating what's possible through your own example. The classical I Ching hexagram emphasizes union and holding together—water on earth creates cohesion. In Human Design's reinterpretation, this becomes about your relationship to being a role model or example. If this gate is defined in your Throat (the center of manifestation and expression), there's consistent energy for contributing by being yourself authentically and letting others learn from what you model. You're not teaching directly; you're inspiring by example. If undefined, you might contribute in other ways or be more private about your process. The shadow is performing authenticity (trying to be a role model without actually being authentic), or hiding your gifts because you don't want the visibility that comes with modeling. The gift is realizing that your authentic expression naturally contributes to the collective—you don't have to force it or manufacture it. When you're genuinely yourself, others learn something simply from witnessing your unique way of being. You contribute through honest self-expression, not through trying to set an example. Practically, this gate often manifests as feeling energized by visibility and authenticity, even when uncomfortable. You might be the friend whose honesty gives others permission to be honest, or the colleague whose unique approach opens possibilities for the team. The contemplative question is about your relationship to visibility, modeling, and contribution through authentic being.

sections.Image: Wind moves across heaven: taming power of the small. The superior one refines the outward aspect of their character.
sections.Line 1: Return to the way. How could this be a mistake? Good fortune. Focus returns to fundamentals before proceeding.
sections.Line 2: Allowing oneself to be drawn into returning. Good fortune. Focus sustained through gentle re-engagement.
sections.Line 3: The spokes burst from the wagon wheels. Man and wife turn eyes away. Focus scattered by competing demands.
sections.Line 4: If sincere, blood vanishes and fear gives way. No blame. Authentic focus dissolves obstacles.
sections.Line 5: If sincere and loyally attached, you are rich in your neighbor. Focused attention creates mutual abundance.
sections.Line 6: The rain comes, there is rest. Due to lasting effect of character. Focus sustained brings breakthrough.
sections.Judgment: The taming power of the small has success. Dense clouds but no rain from the western region.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 9 in the Sacral Center represents the power of focus on details—the capacity to concentrate life force energy on small, specific elements that accumulate into larger patterns. This isn't about missing the forest for the trees; it's about recognizing that forests are made of individual trees, each deserving attention. The classical hexagram shows wind gathering clouds without yet producing rain—potential building through patient accumulation of small elements. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes your relationship to detailed focus: can you sustain attention on specifics without losing sight of the whole? If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's consistent energy for detailed work. You might be the person who notices what others miss, who can work with sustained attention on seemingly minor elements, who finds meaning in precision. If undefined, your focus tends toward the general or big picture, learning about detail orientation from others. The shadow appears when detail focus becomes perfectionism, when attention to small things masks avoidance of larger challenges, or when you get so lost in specifics that synthesis becomes impossible. The gift is precision that serves purpose—you can zoom in without losing perspective, attend to particulars while maintaining awareness of how they fit into wholes. You recognize that breakthrough often emerges from careful attention to what seems small rather than grasping for the dramatic. Practically, this gate often manifests as natural ability for detailed work, enjoyment of tasks others find tedious, and capacity to find patterns in specifics. Whether this reflects actual energetic wiring or is useful metaphor for different cognitive styles remains contemplative territory.

sections.Image: Heaven above, the lake below: treading. The superior one discriminates between high and low and thereby fortifies the thinking of the people.
sections.Line 1: Simple conduct. Progress without blame. Behavior flows from authentic simplicity.
sections.Line 2: Treading a smooth level course. Perseverance brings good fortune. Steady authentic behavior.
sections.Line 3: A one-eyed person can see, a lame person can tread. Steps on tiger's tail—it bites. Behavior overreaching capacity.
sections.Line 4: Steps on tiger's tail. Caution and circumspection lead to ultimate good fortune. Authentic but careful conduct.
sections.Line 5: Resolute conduct. Perseverance with awareness of danger. Bold authentic behavior with eyes open.
sections.Line 6: Look to your conduct and weigh the favorable signs. Supreme good fortune. Self-reflective authentic behavior.
sections.Judgment: Treading upon the tail of the tiger—it does not bite. Success.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 10 in the G Center represents behavior of the self—how you naturally conduct yourself in the world, your authentic way of being that comes from self-love rather than performance. The classical hexagram suggests treading carefully in dangerous places, walking the tiger's tail without getting bitten through proper conduct. In Human Design's framework, this becomes about whether your behavior flows from genuine self-acceptance or from trying to be what you think you should be. If this gate is defined in your G Center, there's consistent energy for authentic self-conduct. You might be someone who naturally behaves in ways that feel true to yourself, even when unconventional. Your behavior isn't calculated for effect; it emerges from self-love. If undefined, your behavior is more flexible and adaptive, learning different modes of conduct from various situations and people. The shadow appears when behavior becomes performance—when you're so focused on conducting yourself 'correctly' that authenticity disappears, or when self-love hardens into narcissism where only your way is valid. The gift is natural authenticity—your behavior reflects genuine self-acceptance, which paradoxically makes it easier for others to be authentic around you. You tread carefully not from fear but from respect for both yourself and others. You can be fully yourself without trampling on others' right to be themselves. Practically, this gate often shows up as people saying 'you're always so yourself' or 'I can be myself around you.' Whether this reflects energetic design or useful language for self-acceptance remains open for contemplation.

sections.Image: Heaven and earth unite: the image of peace. The sovereign divides and completes the course of heaven and earth.
sections.Line 1: When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it. Each according to their kind. Undertakings bring good fortune. Ideas emerge in clusters.
sections.Line 2: Bearing with the uncultured in gentleness, fording the river with resolution. Ideas require both openness and determination.
sections.Line 3: No plain not followed by a slope. No going not followed by a return. Ideas cycle naturally.
sections.Line 4: Flutters down, not boasting of wealth, together with neighbors. Ideas shared create community.
sections.Line 5: The sovereign gives his daughter in marriage. This brings blessing and supreme good fortune. Ideas find perfect implementation.
sections.Line 6: The city wall falls back into the moat. Use no army now. Ideas dissolve back into potential when their time passes.
sections.Judgment: Peace. The small departs, the great approaches. Good fortune. Success.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 11 in the Ajna Center represents ideas and concepts—the mental capacity to receive and generate abstract thoughts that may or may not have immediate practical application. The classical hexagram shows heaven and earth in harmonious union, suggesting that peace emerges when higher and lower, abstract and concrete, find alignment. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes your relationship to ideas: do you have consistent access to conceptual thinking, or is your mind more focused on immediate practical matters? If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular energy for idea generation. You might be someone who has lots of ideas, who lives partly in the realm of concepts, who can think abstractly with ease. People might come to you for new perspectives or unusual angles. If undefined, your thinking is more grounded in what's immediately relevant, learning about abstract ideation from others. The shadow is either idea addiction (so many concepts that nothing gets implemented) or getting lost in mental realms disconnected from embodied reality. The gift is idea generation that serves life—you can think conceptually without losing touch with what matters on the ground. Your ideas create peace rather than confusion because they help people see new possibilities without demanding they abandon practical wisdom. Practically, this gate often manifests as being 'the idea person' in groups, having insights that seem to come from nowhere, or finding that your best contribution is conceptual rather than implementation-focused. This is contemplative territory for exploring how abstract thinking serves lived experience.

sections.Image: Heaven and earth do not unite: the image of standstill. The superior one falls back upon their inner worth to escape difficulties.
sections.Line 1: When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it. Perseverance brings good fortune and success. Cautious withdrawal from premature expression.
sections.Line 2: They bear and endure; this means good fortune for inferior people. The standstill serves success of the great one. Caution as service.
sections.Line 3: They bear shame. Recognition that the time for expression hasn't arrived.
sections.Line 4: One who acts at the command of the highest remains without blame. Cautious expression under proper authority.
sections.Line 5: Standstill is giving way. Good fortune for the great one. What if it should fail? Caution relaxing as timing shifts.
sections.Line 6: The standstill comes to an end. First standstill, then good fortune. Caution gives way to expression.
sections.Judgment: Standstill. Evil people do not further the perseverance of the superior one. The great departs; the small approaches.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 12 in the Throat Center represents caution in expression—knowing when to speak and when to remain silent, when to articulate what you know and when to wait for right timing. The classical hexagram shows heaven and earth separated, communication blocked, suggesting that sometimes standstill is the appropriate response rather than forced movement. In Human Design's reading, this becomes your relationship to expressing yourself: do you have consistent access to knowing when to speak versus when to pause? If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular energy for discerning right timing of expression. You might be someone who knows when words will land versus when they'll fall on deaf ears, who can hold back expression when the moment isn't ripe. If undefined, your expression is more spontaneous or learned situationally from others. The shadow appears when caution becomes suppression (never speaking up) or when timing-awareness becomes manipulation (withholding strategically for effect). The gift is wise restraint that serves communication—you know that not everything that can be said should be said, and not every moment is the right moment. Your caution isn't fear; it's respect for the power of words and awareness of readiness in listeners. Practically, this gate often manifests as being told 'you always know the right time to say things' or finding that when you do speak after waiting, people really hear you. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between silence and speech.

sections.Image: Heaven together with fire: the image of fellowship. The superior one organizes clans and makes distinctions between things.
sections.Line 1: Fellowship at the gate. No blame. Listening begins with open invitation.
sections.Line 2: Fellowship with people in the clan. Humiliation. Listening constrained by tribe rather than open.
sections.Line 3: Hides weapons in the thicket. Climbs the high hill. For three years does not rise up. Listening blocked by suspicion.
sections.Line 4: Climbs up on their wall but cannot attack. Good fortune. Listening that maintains boundaries.
sections.Line 5: People bound in fellowship first weep and lament, but afterward they laugh. After great struggles they succeed in meeting. Deep listening through difficulty.
sections.Line 6: Fellowship in the meadow. No remorse. Listening that creates open community.
sections.Judgment: Fellowship with others in the open. Success. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance of the superior one furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 13 in the G Center represents the listener—the capacity to hear and hold others' stories, secrets, and experiences, to serve as witness to what people need to express. The classical hexagram emphasizes fellowship in the open, suggesting that genuine community emerges when people can share openly with those who truly listen. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent energy for deep listening and holding space for others' expression. If this gate is defined in your G Center, there's regular capacity for listening without needing to fix, judge, or redirect. You might be the person people naturally confide in, who can hear difficult truths without collapsing or rejecting. Your listening creates fellowship because people feel genuinely met. If undefined, you learn about deep listening from others and may be more focused on your own expression. The shadow appears when listening becomes passive reception without boundaries, when you're so busy holding others' stories that you lose your own voice, or when 'being a good listener' becomes an identity that prevents authentic relationship. The gift is generative listening—your capacity to hear others actually helps them hear themselves. You don't just receive; your listening creates space for people to discover what they really need to say. Practically, this gate often shows up as 'I don't know why I'm telling you this' or people feeling understood in your presence. This is contemplative territory about the power of being witnessed.

sections.Image: Fire in heaven above: possession in great measure. The superior one curbs evil and furthers good, obedient to the benevolent will of heaven.
sections.Line 1: No relationship with what is harmful. No blame. Blameless if one remains conscious of difficulty. Power used consciously.
sections.Line 2: A big wagon for loading. One may undertake something. No blame. Power can carry weight.
sections.Line 3: A prince offers it to the Son of Heaven. A petty person cannot do this. Power shared with those worthy.
sections.Line 4: Makes no mistake in distinguishing from neighbor. No blame. Power discerning in application.
sections.Line 5: Whose truth is accessible yet dignified obtains good fortune. Power combined with authenticity.
sections.Line 6: Is blessed by heaven. Good fortune. Nothing that does not further. Power blessed by alignment.
sections.Judgment: Possession in great measure. Supreme success.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 14 in the Sacral Center represents power skills—the capacity to develop and wield resources, whether material, energetic, or skillful, and to do so in service of something meaningful. The classical hexagram shows fire in heaven, suggesting that true possession comes from alignment with higher purpose rather than mere accumulation. In Human Design's reading, this becomes your relationship to power and resources: do you have consistent energy for building skills and resources? If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's regular life force available for developing mastery, for accumulating what's needed, for building capacity over time. You might be someone who naturally gets good at things, who can sustain effort toward skill development, who knows how to marshal resources. If undefined, your relationship to power and skills is more situational, learning from others about mastery. The shadow appears when possession becomes hoarding, when power is accumulated for its own sake rather than for service, or when skill development disconnects from purpose. The gift is empowered service—you develop power and skills specifically to serve something beyond yourself. Your resources empower others rather than creating dependency or envy. Practically, this gate often manifests as natural capacity for skill acquisition, comfort with power when it serves purpose, and ability to translate resources into action. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between power and service.

sections.Image: Within the earth, a mountain: modesty. The superior one reduces what is too much and augments what is too little.
sections.Line 1: A superior one modest about modesty. May cross the great water. Good fortune. Modesty naturally expressed.
sections.Line 2: Modesty that comes to expression. Perseverance brings good fortune. Modesty articulated.
sections.Line 3: A superior one of modesty and merit carries things to conclusion. Good fortune. Modesty with competence.
sections.Line 4: Nothing that would not further through modesty in movement. Modesty in action.
sections.Line 5: No boasting of wealth before one's neighbors. Favorable to attack with force. Nothing that does not further. Modesty with power.
sections.Line 6: Modesty that comes to expression. Favorable to set armies marching. Modesty manifesting fully.
sections.Judgment: Modesty creates success. The superior one carries things through.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 15 in the G Center represents extremes—the capacity to experience the full range from high to low, abundance to scarcity, ecstasy to despair, and to find modesty (right relationship) with these extremes rather than identifying with them. The classical hexagram shows a mountain beneath earth, suggesting that true power lies in humility rather than display. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes your relationship to rhythm and extremes: do you naturally move through highs and lows with equanimity, or do extremes destabilize you? If this gate is defined in your G Center, there's consistent energy for riding life's waves without getting lost in either peak or valley. You might be someone who can hold both extremes simultaneously, who knows prosperity and scarcity are temporary, who remains human through all conditions. If undefined, you experience extremes more dramatically or learn about balance from others. The shadow appears when you identify with extremes (becoming manic or depressive rather than experiencing moods), when modesty becomes false humility or self-diminishment, or when balancing extremes means never fully experiencing either. The gift is genuine modesty—you can be extraordinary without losing your humanity, can experience abundance without superiority or scarcity without shame. You know that extremes are natural rhythms, not definitions of worth. Practically, this gate often shows up as resilience through life's ups and downs, capacity to remain grounded during success or failure. This is contemplative territory about identity beyond circumstance.

sections.Image: Thunder comes resounding out of the earth: enthusiasm. The ancient kings made music to honor merit.
sections.Line 1: Enthusiasm that expresses itself brings misfortune. Premature expression of skill.
sections.Line 2: Firm as a rock. Not a whole day. Perseverance brings good fortune. Skill grounded in substance.
sections.Line 3: Enthusiasm that looks upward creates remorse. Hesitation brings remorse. Skill seeking external validation.
sections.Line 4: The source of enthusiasm. Achieves great things. Doubt not. Skill expressed from authentic depth.
sections.Line 5: Persistently ill, yet does not die. Skill sustained through difficulty.
sections.Line 6: Deluded enthusiasm. But if after completion one changes, there is no blame. Skill expressed without awareness, then corrected.
sections.Judgment: Enthusiasm. It furthers one to install helpers and to set armies marching.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 16 in the Throat Center represents skills expressed with enthusiasm—the capacity to articulate your talents, to express your depth of knowledge or ability with genuine excitement that's contagious rather than performative. The classical hexagram shows thunder emerging from earth, suggesting that true enthusiasm comes from depth rather than surface. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent energy for expressing your skills enthusiastically. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular capacity for sharing what you know with natural excitement that engages others. You might be someone whose enthusiasm for your skills is genuine and inspiring, who can express depth accessibly. If undefined, your expression of skills is more neutral or you learn about enthusiastic expression from others. The shadow appears when enthusiasm becomes performance (trying to seem excited to impress), when skill expression becomes showing off, or when fear of appearing too enthusiastic suppresses genuine excitement about what you know. The gift is infectious enthusiasm—your genuine excitement about your skills actually helps others access enthusiasm for theirs. You can express depth without pretension and skill without superiority because your enthusiasm is real, not calculated. Practically, this gate often shows up as being told 'your passion is inspiring' or finding that when you share your skills enthusiastically, people want to learn. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between depth, skill, and genuine excitement.

sections.Image: Thunder in the middle of the lake: following. The superior one at nightfall goes indoors for rest and recuperation.
sections.Line 1: The standard is changing. Perseverance brings good fortune. Going out of the door in company produces deeds. Opinion shifts with new information.
sections.Line 2: If one clings to the little boy, one loses the strong man. Opinion must choose appropriate focus.
sections.Line 3: If one clings to the strong man, one loses the little boy. Through following, one finds what one seeks. Opinion finding right alignment.
sections.Line 4: Following creates success. Perseverance brings misfortune. Opinion needs authentic foundation.
sections.Line 5: Sincere in the good. Good fortune. Opinion aligned with truth.
sections.Line 6: Firmly bound and tied. The king introduces them on the Western Mountain. Opinion recognized and honored.
sections.Judgment: Following has supreme success. Perseverance furthers. No blame.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 17 in the Ajna Center represents opinions—the mental capacity to form perspectives, to organize ideas into coherent viewpoints, and to offer these as possibilities for others to consider or follow. The classical hexagram suggests that following comes naturally when there's something worth following, when opinions serve rather than dominate. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent access to opinion formation. If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular energy for forming mental perspectives. You might be someone who naturally has opinions about things, who can organize disparate information into coherent viewpoints, whose perspectives help others think more clearly. If undefined, your thinking is more open and questioning, sampling opinions from others without needing to form fixed views. The shadow appears when opinions harden into dogma, when you need others to follow your thinking to validate yourself, or when having opinions becomes more important than discovering truth. The gift is helpful perspective—your opinions actually serve others' thinking rather than shutting it down. You can hold views strongly while remaining genuinely curious about other perspectives. Practically, this gate often manifests as people saying 'what's your take on this?' or finding that your perspectives help groups move forward when thinking gets stuck. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between conviction and openness.

sections.Image: The wind blows low on the mountain: decay. The superior one stirs up the people and strengthens their spirit.
sections.Line 1: Setting right what has been spoiled by the father. If there is a son, no blame rests upon the departed father. Correcting inherited patterns.
sections.Line 2: Setting right what has been spoiled by the mother. One must not be too persevering. Correction requires gentleness.
sections.Line 3: Setting right what has been spoiled by the father. There will be little remorse. No great blame. Correction despite imperfect execution.
sections.Line 4: Tolerating what has been spoiled by the father. Going on brings humiliation. Correction requires action, not tolerance.
sections.Line 5: Setting right what has been spoiled by the father. One meets with praise. Correction recognized and valued.
sections.Line 6: Does not serve kings and princes, sets himself higher goals. Correction serving higher purpose than power.
sections.Judgment: Work on what has been spoiled has supreme success. It furthers one to cross the great water. Before the starting point, three days. After the starting point, three days.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 18 in the Spleen Center represents correction—the instinctual capacity to recognize what's not working, what needs repair or improvement, and to challenge patterns that have become corrupt or dysfunctional. The classical hexagram addresses decay and the work required to address what has spoiled, suggesting that correction is not just criticism but active repair. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent instinctual knowing about what needs fixing. If this gate is defined in your Spleen, there's regular intuitive capacity for seeing what's wrong and feeling compelled to address it. You might be someone who naturally spots problems, who can't let dysfunction continue unchallenged, whose corrections ultimately serve health. If undefined, you're less focused on what's wrong and may need others to point out problems. The shadow appears when correction becomes constant criticism without constructive action, when perfectionism makes everything seem broken, or when you focus so much on what's wrong that you miss what's working. The gift is healing judgment—your capacity to see dysfunction actually helps systems repair themselves. You challenge not to destroy but to restore health. Practically, this gate often manifests as being the person who says what everyone's thinking but won't say, whose challenges ultimately strengthen rather than weaken systems. This is contemplative territory about the difference between destructive criticism and healing correction.

sections.Image: The earth above the lake: approach. The superior one is inexhaustible in their will to teach, and without limits in their tolerance and protection of the people.
sections.Line 1: Joint approach. Perseverance brings good fortune. Wanting addressed collectively.
sections.Line 2: Joint approach. Good fortune. Everything furthers. Wanting met through connection.
sections.Line 3: Comfortable approach. Nothing that would further. Wanting without sensitivity.
sections.Line 4: Complete approach. No blame. Wanting fully acknowledged.
sections.Line 5: Wise approach. This is right for a great prince. Good fortune. Wanting met with wisdom.
sections.Line 6: Greathearted approach. Good fortune. No blame. Wanting held with generous spirit.
sections.Judgment: Approach has supreme success. Perseverance furthers. When the eighth month comes, there will be misfortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 19 in the Root Center represents wanting—the pressure to approach basic needs, to be sensitive to what's required for survival and thriving, and to ensure that fundamental resources are available. The classical hexagram suggests approach as both movement toward what's needed and the way needs approach us as demands. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure around needs and resources. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular awareness of what's needed—not just for you but often for others or the collective. You might be someone who's keenly aware of resource issues, who can't ignore when basic needs aren't met, who feels pressure to ensure adequacy. If undefined, you're less focused on need states and may experience wanting in waves or learn about it from others. The shadow appears when sensitivity to needs becomes anxiety about scarcity, when wanting becomes grasping that never feels satisfied, or when awareness of others' needs leads to martyrdom or resentment. The gift is sensitive provision—your awareness of what's truly needed helps resources flow where they serve life. You can distinguish real needs from manufactured wants. Practically, this gate often manifests as noticing when someone needs something before they ask, organizing resource sharing, or feeling unable to rest when basic needs are unmet around you. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between need, want, and sufficiency.

sections.Image: The wind blows over the earth: contemplation. The ancient kings visited the regions of the world, contemplated the people, and gave them instruction.
sections.Line 1: Boylike contemplation. For an inferior person, no blame. For a superior person, humiliation. Superficial presence.
sections.Line 2: Contemplation through the crack of the door. Furthering for the perseverance of a woman. Limited presence.
sections.Line 3: Contemplation of my life decides the choice between advance and retreat. Presence revealing direction.
sections.Line 4: Contemplation of the light of the kingdom. It furthers one to exert influence as the guest of a king. Presence recognized.
sections.Line 5: Contemplation of my life. The superior one is without blame. Self-reflective presence.
sections.Line 6: Contemplation of their life. The superior one is without blame. Presence observing life as it is.
sections.Judgment: Contemplation. The ablution has been made, but not yet the offering. Full of trust they look up to him.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 20 in the Throat Center represents the now—the capacity to be present in this moment and to express from that presence rather than from memory or anticipation. The classical hexagram emphasizes contemplation as a form of knowing through witnessing, through being truly present to what is. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to present-moment awareness that you can articulate. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular capacity for expressing from nowness. You might be someone who speaks from what's actually happening rather than from scripts, whose words have immediacy and presence, who can bring people into the present moment through your expression. If undefined, your expression may be more conceptual or historical, learning about presence from others. The shadow appears when 'being present' becomes a spiritual performance, when you use nowness to avoid responsibility for past or future, or when you're so focused on this moment that you lose continuity. The gift is genuine presence—your expression comes from actually being here, which helps others arrive too. You can articulate the present moment in ways that wake people up from habitual patterns. Practically, this gate often manifests as people saying 'you really see me' or finding that your words land with unusual impact because they come from true presence. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between awareness and expression.

sections.Image: Thunder and lightning: biting through. The ancient kings made firm the laws through clearly defined penalties.
sections.Line 1: Feet are fastened in the stocks. Toes disappear. No blame. Control restrained from overreach.
sections.Line 2: Bites through tender meat, so that the nose disappears. No blame. Control easily applied.
sections.Line 3: Bites on old dried meat and strikes on something poisonous. Slight humiliation. No blame. Control meeting resistance.
sections.Line 4: Bites on dried gristly meat. Receives metal arrows. Control requiring sustained effort.
sections.Line 5: Bites on dried lean meat. Receives yellow gold. Control aligned with value.
sections.Line 6: Neck fastened in wooden cangue, so that ears disappear. Misfortune. Control overextended.
sections.Judgment: Biting through has success. It is favorable to let justice be administered.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 21 in the Heart/Ego Center represents control—the willful capacity to manage resources, to maintain authority over what belongs to you, and to bite through obstacles when necessary. The classical hexagram uses the metaphor of biting through something that blocks the mouth, suggesting that force is sometimes required for breakthrough. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent access to willpower and resource management. If this gate is defined in your Heart/Ego, there's regular capacity for taking control when needed. You might be someone who can manage resources effectively, who has natural authority, who can apply will to break through resistance. If undefined, your relationship to control and authority is more fluid, learning from others about effective management. The shadow appears when control becomes domination, when willpower overrides wisdom, or when you need to control everything to feel safe. The gift is right use of authority—your capacity to control serves larger purposes rather than ego gratification. You know when to take charge and when to release control. Practically, this gate often manifests as people naturally looking to you to manage resources or make executive decisions, or finding that you can break through stuck situations through clear authority. This is contemplative territory about power, control, and service.

sections.Image: Fire at the foot of the mountain: grace. The superior one brings clarity to all matters of government but dares not decide controversial issues.
sections.Line 1: Lends grace to the toes. Leaves the carriage and walks. Grace in simple action.
sections.Line 2: Lends grace to the beard on the chin. Grace naturally expressed.
sections.Line 3: Graceful and moist. Constant perseverance brings good fortune. Grace sustained over time.
sections.Line 4: Grace or simplicity? A white horse comes as if on wings. Grace choosing between adornment and simplicity.
sections.Line 5: Grace in hills and gardens. The roll of silk is meager and small. Humiliation, but in the end good fortune. Grace in modest form.
sections.Line 6: Simple grace. No blame. Grace without artifice.
sections.Judgment: Grace has success. In small matters it is favorable to undertake something.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 22 in the Solar Plexus Center represents grace and openness—the emotional capacity to listen without agenda, to be receptive to others' feelings and expressions, and to respond with grace rather than reactivity. The classical hexagram uses adornment as metaphor, suggesting that true grace is not superficial decoration but the natural beauty that emerges from inner clarity. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent emotional openness to receive others. If this gate is defined in your Solar Plexus, there's regular capacity for emotional listening and graceful response. You might be someone who can hear difficult emotions without defending, whose openness helps others express what's really happening emotionally. If undefined, your emotional openness comes in waves or is learned situationally. The shadow appears when openness becomes doormat energy where you receive everything without boundaries, when grace becomes performance masking inner turmoil, or when you're so open to others' emotions that you lose your own. The gift is graceful receptivity—your emotional openness actually helps others find their own emotional clarity. You can listen to intense feelings without collapsing or fixing. Practically, this gate often manifests as people feeling safe to express difficult emotions around you, or finding that your graceful presence helps de-escalate emotional intensity. This is contemplative territory about emotional boundaries and genuine openness.

sections.Image: The mountain rests on the earth: splitting apart. The superior one through generosity toward their subordinates ensures their own position.
sections.Line 1: The leg of the bed is split. Those who persevere are destroyed. Misfortune. Foundation of understanding compromised.
sections.Line 2: The bed is split at the edge. Those who persevere are destroyed. Misfortune. Understanding dissolving.
sections.Line 3: Splits with them. No blame. Necessary dissolution of false understanding.
sections.Line 4: The bed is split up to the skin. Misfortune. Understanding deeply compromised.
sections.Line 5: A shoal of fishes. Favor comes through the court ladies. Everything acts to further. Understanding finding new form.
sections.Line 6: There is a large fruit still uneaten. The superior one obtains a carriage. Understanding preserved through dissolution.
sections.Judgment: Splitting apart. It does not further one to go anywhere.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 23 in the Throat Center represents assimilation—the capacity to take in complex information and split it apart into understandable pieces that can be expressed to others. The classical hexagram warns about times when things are falling apart and suggests knowing when to act versus when to wait. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent capacity to break down complexity and express it clearly. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular energy for assimilating and explaining. You might be someone who can take complicated concepts and make them accessible, who explains things so others understand, whose gift is translating complexity into clarity. If undefined, your expression may be more about feeling or direct experience than explanation. The shadow appears when assimilation becomes over-simplification that loses essential nuance, when you explain things to death rather than letting people discover, or when your capacity to split things apart becomes destructive analysis. The gift is clarifying complexity—your ability to break things down actually helps people engage with difficult material. You make the complex approachable without dumbing it down. Practically, this gate often manifests as being asked to explain things, writing clear documentation, or finding that your ability to articulate complexity serves groups. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between complexity and accessibility.

sections.Image: Thunder within the earth: return. The ancient kings closed the passes at the time of solstice. Merchants and strangers did not go about, and the ruler did not travel through the provinces.
sections.Line 1: Return from a short distance. No need for remorse. Great good fortune. Thought returning easily.
sections.Line 2: Quiet return. Good fortune. Thought returning gracefully.
sections.Line 3: Repeated return. Danger. No blame. Thought cycling necessarily.
sections.Line 4: Walking in the midst of others, one returns alone. Thought returning independently.
sections.Line 5: Noblehearted return. No remorse. Thought returning with integrity.
sections.Line 6: Missing the return. Misfortune. Thought failing to return when needed.
sections.Judgment: Return. Success. Going out and coming in without error. Friends come without blame. To and fro goes the way. On the seventh day comes return.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 24 in the Ajna Center represents return—the mental capacity to come back to thoughts, to rationalize and re-think, to cycle through ideas until understanding clarifies. The classical hexagram emphasizes natural cycles of return, the way things come back around at their proper time. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent mental energy for returning to thoughts. If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular capacity for mental cycling. You might be someone who thinks about things repeatedly, who returns to ideas to refine understanding, whose thinking has a spiraling quality that deepens over time. If undefined, your thinking is more linear or you move on from ideas rather than cycling back. The shadow appears when return becomes obsessive rumination, when you can't let thoughts go even when they're resolved, or when cycling back becomes avoidance of moving forward. The gift is deepening understanding—your capacity to return to thoughts actually helps you discover layers that weren't visible on first pass. You know that understanding often requires multiple returns, that the seventh day brings different insight than the first. Practically, this gate often manifests as people saying 'I've been thinking more about what you said' or finding that your best insights come when you return to questions you thought you'd finished with. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between repetition and depth.

sections.Image: Under heaven thunder rolls: innocence. The ancient kings nourished all beings richly in accord with the time.
sections.Line 1: Innocent behavior brings good fortune. Spirit naturally expressed.
sections.Line 2: If one does not count on the harvest while plowing, success comes of itself. Spirit trusting process.
sections.Line 3: Undeserved misfortune. The cow that was tethered by someone is the wanderer's gain. Spirit meeting circumstance.
sections.Line 4: He who can be persevering remains without blame. Spirit sustained.
sections.Line 5: Use no medicine in an illness incurred through no fault of your own. Spirit healing naturally.
sections.Line 6: Innocent action brings misfortune. Nothing furthers. Spirit acting out of timing.
sections.Judgment: Innocence. Supreme success. Perseverance furthers. If someone is not as they should be, they have misfortune, and it does not further them to undertake anything.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 25 in the Heart/Ego Center represents the spirit of the self—the innocent, spontaneous expression of who you are before conditioning, before trying to be someone. The classical hexagram emphasizes acting from natural alignment rather than calculated strategy. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to innocent, unconditional love and spontaneous self-expression. If this gate is defined in your Heart/Ego, there's regular capacity for being innocently yourself, for universal love that doesn't require earning. You might be someone who radiates unconditional acceptance, whose presence reminds others of innocence. If undefined, you experience innocence in waves or learn about unconditional love from others. The shadow appears when innocence becomes naiveté that refuses to see reality, when spirit bypasses necessary development, or when unconditional love becomes inability to set boundaries. The gift is genuine innocence—not childishness but the capacity to meet life freshly without armoring, to love without agenda. You can be fully in the world while maintaining contact with unconditioned spirit. Practically, this gate often manifests as people feeling unconditionally accepted in your presence, or finding that you can see the innocent self in others even when they've lost touch with it. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between innocence and maturity.

sections.Image: Heaven within the mountain: taming power of the great. The superior one acquires knowledge of many sayings of antiquity and deeds of the past to strengthen their character.
sections.Line 1: Danger is at hand. It furthers one to desist. Ego restraining premature action.
sections.Line 2: The axletrees are taken from the wagon. Ego power temporarily restrained.
sections.Line 3: A good horse follows. Awareness of danger and perseverance further. Ego power finding right direction.
sections.Line 4: The headboard of a young bull. Great good fortune. Ego power developed early.
sections.Line 5: The tusk of a gelded boar. Good fortune. Ego power tamed constructively.
sections.Line 6: One attains the way of heaven. Success. Ego power aligned with higher purpose.
sections.Judgment: The taming power of the great. Perseverance furthers. Not eating at home brings good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 26 in the Heart/Ego Center represents the egoist—the capacity to have a strong, integrated sense of self that serves through taming great power. This isn't ego in the negative sense but self-integrity that can contain and direct substantial force. The classical hexagram emphasizes accumulating and taming power through discipline. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent access to ego strength and the capacity to sell or influence. If this gate is defined in your Heart/Ego, there's regular willpower and self-integrity. You might be someone with strong ego in the positive sense, who can accumulate resources and influence, who has natural sales ability. If undefined, your relationship to ego and influence is more situational. The shadow appears when ego becomes narcissism, when taming power becomes controlling everything, or when selling becomes manipulation. The gift is integrated strength—your ego is strong enough to contain great power without being corrupted by it. You can influence and sell ethically because your integrity remains intact. Practically, this gate often manifests as natural ability to influence others, comfort with ego strength, or finding that people trust you to handle power responsibly. This is contemplative territory about ego, power, and integrity.

sections.Image: At the foot of the mountain, thunder: nourishment. The superior one is careful of their words and temperate in eating and drinking.
sections.Line 1: You let your magic tortoise go and look at me with the corners of your mouth drooping. Misfortune. Caring seeking external validation.
sections.Line 2: Turning to the summit for nourishment, deviating from the path to seek nourishment from the hill. Caring from wrong source.
sections.Line 3: Turning away from nourishment. Perseverance brings misfortune. Caring refused.
sections.Line 4: Turning to the summit for provision of nourishment brings good fortune. Caring from right source.
sections.Line 5: Turning away from the path. Remain persevering brings good fortune. Caring with discernment.
sections.Line 6: The source of nourishment. Awareness of danger brings good fortune. Caring from deep source.
sections.Judgment: Nourishment. Perseverance brings good fortune. Pay heed to the providing of nourishment and to what a person seeks to fill their mouth with.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 27 in the Sacral Center represents caring and nourishment—the life force energy for taking care of others, for providing what's needed, for nourishing both literally and metaphorically. The classical hexagram emphasizes both physical nourishment and being careful about what we take in and express. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent sacral energy for caregiving. If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's regular life force available for caring. You might be someone who naturally takes care of others, who has energy for nourishing, who feels responsible for others' wellbeing. If undefined, you experience caring in waves or learn about nurturing from others. The shadow appears when caring becomes caretaking that depletes you, when responsibility becomes martyrdom, or when you only feel valuable when nourishing others. The gift is sustainable caring—your capacity to nourish actually regenerates you because it comes from genuine life force rather than obligation. You know the difference between healthy caregiving and codependence. Practically, this gate often manifests as people naturally turning to you for care, finding that you have energy for nurturing that doesn't deplete, or discovering that caring for others is how you express your life force. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between caring and depletion.

sections.Image: The lake rises above the trees: preponderance of the great. The superior one stands alone without fear and retreats from the world without regret.
sections.Line 1: To spread white rushes underneath. No blame. Risk approached with care.
sections.Line 2: A dry poplar sprouts at the root. An older man takes a young wife. Everything furthers. Risk generating new life.
sections.Line 3: The ridgepole sags to the breaking point. Misfortune. Risk exceeding capacity.
sections.Line 4: The ridgepole is braced. Good fortune. Risk supported appropriately.
sections.Line 5: A withered poplar puts forth flowers. An older woman takes a husband. Risk in unlikely circumstances.
sections.Line 6: One must go through the water. It goes over one's head. Misfortune. No blame. Risk accepted despite cost.
sections.Judgment: Preponderance of the great. The ridgepole sags to the breaking point. It furthers one to have somewhere to go. Success.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 28 in the Spleen Center represents risk—the instinctual knowing about when struggle is worthwhile, when taking risks serves purpose, when the game is worth playing despite difficulty. The classical hexagram warns of excess weight, the ridgepole bending, suggesting that sometimes carrying too much requires action. In Human Design's interpretation, this becomes whether you have consistent instinctual knowing about meaningful risk. If this gate is defined in your Spleen, there's regular intuitive capacity for assessing when struggle serves purpose. You might be someone who knows instinctually which battles to fight, who can engage with risk when it matters, who understands that some purposes require accepting challenge. If undefined, you experience risk assessment in the moment or learn from others about purposeful struggle. The shadow appears when you seek struggle for its own sake, when every challenge seems worth taking, or when you avoid all risk and miss meaningful purpose. The gift is purposeful risk—you know which struggles serve life and which just exhaust. You can engage with challenge when it matters without becoming addicted to difficulty. Practically, this gate often manifests as people trusting your judgment about which risks are worthwhile, or finding that you're willing to struggle for what truly matters while letting go of meaningless conflict. This is contemplative territory about purpose and risk.

sections.Image: Water flows on uninterruptedly and reaches its goal: the abysmal repeated. The superior one walks in lasting virtue and carries on teaching.
sections.Line 1: Repetition of the abysmal. In the abyss one falls into a pit. Misfortune. Commitment to danger.
sections.Line 2: The abyss is dangerous. One should strive to attain small things only. Commitment with modest goals.
sections.Line 3: Forward and backward, abyss on abyss. In danger like this, pause at first and wait. Commitment requiring patience.
sections.Line 4: A jug of wine, a bowl of rice with it. Simple offering in earthenware. Commitment to simplicity.
sections.Line 5: The abyss is not filled to overflowing. It is filled only to the rim. No blame. Commitment without excess.
sections.Line 6: Bound with cords and ropes, shut in between thorn-hedged prison walls. For three years one does not find the way. Misfortune. Commitment trapped.
sections.Judgment: The Abysmal repeated. If you are sincere, you have success in your heart, and whatever you do succeeds.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 29 in the Sacral Center represents commitment—the sacral energy to say yes fully, to commit life force to what you engage with, to stay with things even when they're difficult. The classical hexagram shows water doubled, emphasizing persistence through danger. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent sacral power for commitment. If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's regular life force available for sustained engagement. You might be someone who commits deeply to what you say yes to, who has staying power, whose perseverance is remarkable. If undefined, commitment comes in waves or you learn about perseverance from others. The shadow appears when commitment becomes inability to quit what's no longer serving, when you stay with things from obligation rather than genuine yes, or when perseverance becomes stubbornness. The gift is full engagement—when you commit, it's with your whole life force, which paradoxically means you only commit to what deserves that energy. You know the difference between wise perseverance and pointless persistence. Practically, this gate often manifests as remarkable follow-through on what you commit to, or finding that you need to be very selective about what you say yes to because once you're in, you're really in. This is contemplative territory about commitment and discernment.

sections.Image: Brightness rises twice: the image of fire. The great one, by perpetuating this brightness, illuminates the four quarters of the world.
sections.Line 1: The footprints run crisscross. If one is seriously intent, no blame. Feelings requiring careful attention.
sections.Line 2: Yellow light. Supreme good fortune. Feelings in balanced expression.
sections.Line 3: In the light of the setting sun, people beat the pot and sing. But the truly old weep. Feelings meeting mortality.
sections.Line 4: Its coming is sudden. It flames up, dies down, is thrown away. Feelings burning intensely then passing.
sections.Line 5: In flood of tears, sighing and lamenting. Good fortune. Feelings fully expressed.
sections.Line 6: The king uses them to march forth and chastise. It is best to kill the leaders and take captive the followers. Feelings directed with precision.
sections.Judgment: The Clinging. Perseverance furthers. It brings success. Care of the cow brings good fortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 30 in the Solar Plexus Center represents recognition of feelings—the emotional capacity to acknowledge desire, to recognize what you truly feel beyond what you think you should feel, to allow feelings their full intensity. The classical hexagram shows fire doubled, suggesting both illumination and the consuming nature of intensity. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to emotional intensity and desire. If this gate is defined in your Solar Plexus, there's regular experience of strong feelings. You might be someone who feels things intensely, who recognizes and honors desire, whose emotional life is rich and sometimes overwhelming. If undefined, you experience emotional intensity in waves or sample it from others. The shadow appears when intensity becomes addiction to drama, when you cling to feelings beyond their natural duration, or when recognizing desire means you must act on every feeling. The gift is emotional clarity—your capacity to recognize and honor feelings without being consumed by them. You know that feelings are information, not commands. Practically, this gate often manifests as helping others recognize their true feelings, or finding that your emotional intensity, when honored rather than suppressed, actually illuminates what matters. This is contemplative territory about the relationship between feelings and fate.

sections.Image: A lake on the mountain: influence. The superior one encourages people to approach and accepts them.
sections.Line 1: The influence shows itself in the big toe. Influence beginning to manifest.
sections.Line 2: The influence shows itself in the calves of the legs. Misfortune. Tarrying brings good fortune. Influence requiring patience.
sections.Line 3: The influence shows itself in the thighs. Holds to that which follows it. Influence through connection.
sections.Line 4: Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears. Influence sustained appropriately.
sections.Line 5: The influence shows itself in the back of the neck. No remorse. Influence through backbone.
sections.Line 6: The influence shows itself in the jaws, cheeks, and tongue. Influence through speech.
sections.Judgment: Influence. Success. Perseverance furthers. Taking a maiden to wife brings good fortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 31 in the Throat Center represents influence through leadership—the capacity to express in ways that naturally lead others, not through dominance but through articulating what needs to be said. The classical hexagram emphasizes mutual attraction and influence. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent capacity to influence through your voice. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular energy for leadership expression.
