You might be someone whose words carry weight, who influences through what you say, who naturally leads when speaking. If undefined, your influence is more situational or expressed through other means. The shadow appears when influence becomes manipulation, when you use voice to control rather than serve, or when you're so focused on influencing that you stop listening. The gift is democratic leadership—your influence comes from saying what serves the collective rather than what serves your ego. You lead with words that empower rather than diminish. Practically, this gate often manifests as people following your suggestions, your words shaping group direction, or finding that when you speak up, things shift. This is contemplative territory about voice, influence, and service.

sections.Image: Thunder and wind: duration. The superior one stands firm and does not change their direction.
sections.Line 1: Seeking duration too hastily brings misfortune persistently. Continuity forced prematurely.
sections.Line 2: Remorse disappears. Continuity naturally established.
sections.Line 3: He who does not give duration to his character meets with disgrace. Continuity of self required.
sections.Line 4: No game in the field. Continuity searching wrong place.
sections.Line 5: Giving duration to one's character through perseverance. Continuity of integrity.
sections.Line 6: Restlessness as an enduring condition brings misfortune. Continuity of instability.
sections.Judgment: Duration. Success. No blame. Perseverance furthers. It furthers one to have somewhere to go.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 32 in the Spleen Center represents continuity—the instinctual knowing about what has lasting value, what deserves to be preserved, and what transformation or failure might mean. The classical hexagram emphasizes endurance through maintaining what's essential while adapting form. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent intuitive knowing about duration and value. If this gate is defined in your Spleen, there's regular instinctual capacity for assessing what lasts. You might be someone who knows what has staying power, who can sense when things will endure versus when they're temporary, whose intuition guides decisions about preservation. If undefined, you assess continuity intellectually or learn from others' intuitive hits. The shadow appears when preservation becomes rigid conservation that prevents necessary change, when you hold onto everything fearing loss, or when intuition about duration makes you unable to let go. The gift is wise preservation—you know what deserves continuation and what needs to end. You can honor duration while allowing transformation. Practically, this gate often manifests as being right about what will last, sensing when systems are failing before evidence appears, or helping others distinguish between temporary trends and lasting value. This is contemplative territory about preservation and change.

sections.Image: Mountain under heaven: retreat. The superior one keeps the inferior person at a distance, not angrily but with reserve.
sections.Line 1: At the tail in retreat. This is dangerous. One must not wish to undertake anything. Privacy as vulnerable position.
sections.Line 2: Holding fast with yellow oxhide. No one can tear him loose. Privacy firmly maintained.
sections.Line 3: A halted retreat is nerve-wracking and dangerous. Privacy compromised causes stress.
sections.Line 4: Voluntary retreat brings good fortune to the superior one. Privacy chosen wisely.
sections.Line 5: Friendly retreat. Perseverance brings good fortune. Privacy maintained gracefully.
sections.Line 6: Cheerful retreat. Everything serves to further. Privacy complete and liberating.
sections.Judgment: Retreat. Success. In small matters, perseverance furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 33 in the Throat Center represents privacy—the capacity to retreat from public expression, to keep things private until the right moment, to know when withdrawal serves rather than hinders. The classical hexagram emphasizes strategic retreat as wisdom rather than cowardice. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent energy for privacy and selective disclosure. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular capacity for keeping things private, for knowing what to share and what to hold back. You might be someone who values privacy, who shares selectively, who knows that some things need time in private before public expression. If undefined, you may share more readily or learn about privacy boundaries from others. The shadow appears when privacy becomes secrecy that isolates, when retreat becomes avoidance of necessary engagement, or when you withhold from fear rather than wisdom. The gift is discerning privacy—you know what deserves protection and what needs sharing. Your capacity to retreat and reflect actually makes your eventual expression more powerful. Practically, this gate often manifests as being selective about what you share, valuing alone time for processing, or finding that your privacy helps you express more authentically when you do speak.

sections.Image: Thunder in heaven above: power of the great. The superior one does not tread paths that do not accord with established order.
sections.Line 1: Power in the toes. Continuing brings misfortune. Power beginning to manifest.
sections.Line 2: Perseverance brings good fortune. Power sustained appropriately.
sections.Line 3: The inferior person works through power. The superior one does not act thus. Power misapplied.
sections.Line 4: Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears. Power breaking through.
sections.Line 5: Loses the goat with ease. No remorse. Power released without attachment.
sections.Line 6: A goat butts against a hedge. Cannot go backward, cannot go forward. Power trapped.
sections.Judgment: Power of the great. Perseverance furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 34 in the Sacral Center represents pure power—raw sacral life force, the energy to do, to act, to make things happen through sheer capacity to work. The classical hexagram warns that great power requires proper channeling. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to sacral power and force. If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's regular availability of powerful life force energy. You might be someone with remarkable capacity for work, who can sustain effort that exhausts others, whose power is palpable. If undefined, you experience power in waves or learn about sustainable force from others. The shadow appears when power becomes busyness for its own sake, when you use force without purpose, or when having power means you must use it constantly. The gift is empowered action—your capacity for work serves meaningful purpose rather than just keeping busy. You know when to apply power and when to conserve energy. Practically, this gate often manifests as exceptional work capacity, comfort with intense activity, or finding that you need significant outlets for your life force or it becomes restless.

sections.Image: The sun rises over the earth: progress. The superior one brightens their own virtue.
sections.Line 1: Progressing, but turned back. Perseverance brings good fortune. Progress meeting resistance.
sections.Line 2: Progressing, but in sorrow. Perseverance brings good fortune. Progress despite difficulty.
sections.Line 3: All are in accord. Remorse disappears. Progress supported collectively.
sections.Line 4: Progress like a hamster. Perseverance brings danger. Progress without authentic foundation.
sections.Line 5: Remorse disappears. Take not gain and loss to heart. Progress brings good fortune.
sections.Line 6: Making progress with the horns is permissible only for chastising one's own city. Progress requiring correction.
sections.Judgment: Progress. The powerful prince is honored with horses in large numbers. In a single day he is granted audience three times.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 35 in the Throat Center represents progress through change and experience—the capacity to express from lived experience, to share stories of what you've gone through, to articulate change as it unfolds. The classical hexagram emphasizes advancement through proper expression. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent energy for expressing experience and welcoming change. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular capacity for articulating your journey, for expressing change, for sharing experience in ways that progress collective understanding. You might be someone who learns through varied experience, who expresses what you've lived, whose stories serve others. If undefined, you express in other ways or learn about experiential wisdom from others. The shadow appears when change becomes addiction to novelty, when you seek experience just to have stories, or when expressing experience becomes performing rather than authentic sharing. The gift is wisdom through experience—your capacity to welcome change and express what you learn actually helps others navigate their own changes. Practically, this gate often manifests as rich life experience that you can articulate, comfort with change, or finding that sharing your journey helps others.

sections.Image: The light has sunk into the earth: darkening of the light. The superior one lives with the great mass veiling their light, yet still bright.
sections.Line 1: Darkening of the light during flight. Lowers its wings. Crisis requiring retreat.
sections.Line 2: Darkening of the light injures in the left thigh. One gives aid with the strength of a horse. Crisis finding support.
sections.Line 3: Darkening of the light during the hunt in the south. Their great leader is captured. Crisis revealing truth.
sections.Line 4: Penetrates the left side of the belly. One obtains the heart of the darkening of the light. Crisis penetrated.
sections.Line 5: Darkening of the light as with Prince Chi. Perseverance furthers. Crisis maintained with dignity.
sections.Line 6: Not light but darkness. First climbed up to heaven, then plunged into the depths. Crisis complete.
sections.Judgment: Darkening of the light. In adversity it furthers one to be persevering.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 36 in the Solar Plexus Center represents crisis and darkening—the emotional capacity to navigate difficult transitions, to maintain hope through darkness, to learn from crisis without being destroyed by it. The classical hexagram addresses times when light is obscured. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent emotional experience of crisis and transition. If this gate is defined in your Solar Plexus, there's regular emotional depth around crisis states. You might be someone who has experienced significant transitions, who knows darkness intimately, whose emotional wisdom comes from having weathered difficulty. If undefined, you experience crisis less frequently or sample it from others. The shadow appears when crisis becomes identity, when you seek difficulty to feel alive, or when your experience of darkness makes you cynical rather than wise. The gift is crisis wisdom—your capacity to navigate darkness actually helps others find hope in their own difficult transitions. You know that crisis often precedes breakthrough. Practically, this gate often manifests as being the person others turn to during crisis because you understand darkness without fear, or finding that your deepest learning comes through difficult passages.

sections.Image: Wind comes forth from fire: the family. The superior one has substance in their words and duration in their way of life.
sections.Line 1: Firm seclusion within the family. Remorse disappears. Family establishing boundaries.
sections.Line 2: Should not follow whims. Must attend within to the food. Family requiring practical care.
sections.Line 3: When tempers flare in the family, too great severity brings remorse. Family negotiating conflict.
sections.Line 4: She is the treasure of the house. Great good fortune. Family honoring members.
sections.Line 5: As a king he approaches his family. Fear not. Good fortune. Family led with authority.
sections.Line 6: His work commands respect. In the end good fortune comes. Family integrity honored.
sections.Judgment: The family. The perseverance of the woman furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 37 in the Solar Plexus Center represents family and friendship—the emotional capacity to form bargains and agreements that create community, to establish who's in your tribe, to maintain bonds through emotional integrity. The classical hexagram emphasizes the family as foundation of society. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent emotional energy for community bonds and agreements. If this gate is defined in your Solar Plexus, there's regular capacity for forming and maintaining community ties. You might be someone who takes family (blood or chosen) seriously, who makes agreements that stick, whose emotional bonds create tribe. If undefined, your community connections are more fluid or learned from others. The shadow appears when family becomes obligation that traps, when agreements become contracts that constrain rather than support, or when you exclude others to maintain tribal purity. The gift is genuine community—your capacity to form emotional agreements actually creates spaces where people can belong. You know that healthy communities require clear agreements honored emotionally. Practically, this gate often manifests as strong loyalty to your people, capacity to negotiate community agreements, or finding that emotional honesty strengthens rather than threatens bonds.

sections.Image: Above, fire; below, the lake: opposition. The superior one retains their individuality in community.
sections.Line 1: Remorse disappears. Lose your horse, do not run after it. Opposition without attachment.
sections.Line 2: One meets their lord in a narrow street. No blame. Opposition finding alignment.
sections.Line 3: One sees the wagon dragged back, the oxen halted. Opposition meeting resistance.
sections.Line 4: Isolated through opposition. One meets a like-minded man. Opposition finding allies.
sections.Line 5: Remorse disappears. The companion bites through the wrappings. Opposition breaking through.
sections.Line 6: Isolated through opposition, one sees one's companion as a pig covered with dirt. Opposition dissolving in understanding.
sections.Judgment: Opposition. In small matters, good fortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 38 in the Root Center represents the fighter—the pressure to oppose what doesn't serve life, to struggle for what matters, to maintain individuality even against opposition. The classical hexagram shows fire and water moving in opposite directions, natural opposition. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure to fight for meaning. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular pressure to oppose what's wrong, to fight for what matters. You might be someone who can't ignore injustice, who feels compelled to struggle for purpose, whose opposition serves life. If undefined, you experience fighting pressure situationally or learn from others about purposeful opposition. The shadow appears when you fight everything reflexively, when opposition becomes your identity, or when you struggle without purpose just to feel alive. The gift is purposeful opposition—your capacity to fight actually serves life rather than just creating conflict. You know which battles matter and which are distractions. Practically, this gate often manifests as being willing to stand alone for what matters, fighting for others who can't fight for themselves, or finding that your opposition to dysfunction strengthens rather than weakens systems.

sections.Image: Water on the mountain: obstruction. The superior one turns their attention to themselves and molds their character.
sections.Line 1: Going leads to obstructions, coming meets with praise. Provocation requiring retreat.
sections.Line 2: The king's servant is beset by obstruction upon obstruction, but it is not their own fault. Provocation beyond personal control.
sections.Line 3: Going leads to obstructions; hence comes back. Provocation turning inward.
sections.Line 4: Going leads to obstructions, coming leads to union. Provocation finding resolution.
sections.Line 5: In the midst of the greatest obstructions, friends come. Provocation revealing true allies.
sections.Line 6: Going leads to obstructions, coming leads to great good fortune. Provocation complete, wisdom gained.
sections.Judgment: Obstruction. The southwest furthers. The northeast does not further. It furthers one to see the great person. Perseverance brings good fortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 39 in the Root Center represents provocation—the pressure to provoke emotional response, to test bonds, to see what's real through challenging what seems stable. The classical hexagram addresses obstruction as opportunity for reflection. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure to provoke and test. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular pressure to provoke response, to test emotional bonds, to see what's authentic. You might be someone whose presence provokes others (not always intentionally), who tests relationships to see what's real, whose provocations ultimately strengthen what's genuine. If undefined, you experience provocation situationally or are more on the receiving end. The shadow appears when provocation becomes destructive testing that damages rather than strengthens, when you provoke to control rather than to discover, or when you're so provocative that nothing stable can form. The gift is strengthening provocation—your capacity to provoke actually reveals truth and strengthens what's real. You test bonds to discover depth, not to destroy. Practically, this gate often manifests as relationships either deepening or ending around you, provocative questions that get to heart of matters, or finding that what survives your testing is genuinely strong.

sections.Image: Thunder and rain set in: deliverance. The superior one pardons mistakes and forgives misdeeds.
sections.Line 1: Without blame. Deliverance beginning naturally.
sections.Line 2: One kills three foxes in the field and receives a yellow arrow. Deliverance removing obstacles.
sections.Line 3: If a person carries a burden on their back and at the same time rides in a carriage, they tempt robbers to draw near. Deliverance compromised by mixed signals.
sections.Line 4: Deliver yourself from your great toe. Then the companion comes in whom you can trust. Deliverance from minor attachments.
sections.Line 5: If only the superior one can deliver himself, good fortune. Deliverance through integrity.
sections.Line 6: The prince shoots at a hawk on a high wall. He kills it. Deliverance complete.
sections.Judgment: Deliverance. The southwest furthers. If there is no longer anything where one has to go, return brings good fortune. If there is still something where one has to go, hastening brings good fortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 40 in the Heart/Ego Center represents deliverance through aloneness—the willpower to be alone when necessary, to deliver yourself from exhausting community, to restore through solitude. The classical hexagram emphasizes liberation after difficulty. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent willpower for solitude and self-restoration. If this gate is defined in your Heart/Ego, there's regular capacity for being alone without loneliness, for using solitude to restore will. You might be someone who needs alone time to function, who delivers yourself from depletion through solitude, whose willpower requires periodic aloneness. If undefined, you experience aloneness differently or learn from others about restorative solitude. The shadow appears when aloneness becomes isolation that cuts you off from necessary connection, when you use solitude to avoid intimacy, or when you can't tolerate any alone time. The gift is restorative solitude—your capacity to be alone actually strengthens your ability to be with others. You know that genuine connection requires periodic deliverance into self. Practically, this gate often manifests as needing solo time after intense social interaction, finding clarity in solitude, or discovering that your willpower regenerates through being alone.

sections.Image: At the foot of the mountain, the lake: decrease. The superior one controls their anger and restrains their instincts.
sections.Line 1: Going quickly when one's tasks are finished is without blame. But reflect on how much one may decrease others. Contraction considering impact.
sections.Line 2: Perseverance furthers. To undertake something brings misfortune. Contraction requiring patience.
sections.Line 3: When three people journey together, their number decreases by one. Contraction through differentiation.
sections.Line 4: If someone decreases their faults, it makes the other hasten to come and brings joy. Contraction releasing obstacles.
sections.Line 5: Someone does indeed increase them. Ten pairs of tortoises cannot oppose it. Contraction leading to increase.
sections.Line 6: If one is increased without depriving others, there is no blame. Contraction without loss.
sections.Judgment: Decrease combined with sincerity brings supreme good fortune without blame. One may be persevering in this. It furthers one to undertake something. How is this to be carried out? Two small bowls can be used for the sacrifice.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 41 in the Root Center represents contraction—the pressure to begin something new that requires letting go of the old, the fantasy and imagination of what could be before manifestation begins. The classical hexagram addresses decrease as necessary for new growth. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure to imagine and begin new cycles. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular pressure around new beginnings, fantasy about possibilities, the contraction before expansion. You might be someone who feels pressure to start things, who has rich fantasy life about what could be, whose imagination serves as pressure toward manifestation. If undefined, you experience beginning pressure situationally or learn about initiation from others. The shadow appears when fantasy never becomes action, when you're addicted to the beginning phase without following through, or when pressure to start things scatters your energy. The gift is creative imagination—your capacity to fantasize and feel pressure toward beginnings actually helps new things emerge. You honor the contraction phase as necessary preparation. Practically, this gate often manifests as being the person who initiates new cycles, whose fantasies contain seeds of real possibility, or finding that your pressure to begin helps groups move forward.

sections.Image: Wind and thunder: increase. The superior one, seeing what is good, imitates it; having faults, they rid themselves of them.
sections.Line 1: It furthers one to accomplish great deeds. Supreme good fortune. No blame. Growth beginning powerfully.
sections.Line 2: Someone does indeed increase them. Ten pairs of tortoises cannot oppose it. Growth receiving support.
sections.Line 3: One is enriched through unfortunate events. No blame if you are sincere. Growth through difficulty.
sections.Line 4: If you walk in the middle and report to the prince, they will follow. Growth through right action.
sections.Line 5: If in truth you have a kind heart, ask not. Supreme good fortune. Growth through kindness.
sections.Line 6: They bring increase to no one. Someone even strikes them. Growth overextended.
sections.Judgment: Increase. It furthers one to undertake something. It furthers one to cross the great water.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 42 in the Sacral Center represents growth and completion—the sacral life force energy to complete cycles, to grow things to maturity, to finish what was begun. The classical hexagram emphasizes natural increase and expansion. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent sacral energy for completion and growth. If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's regular capacity for bringing things to completion, for growing projects to maturity. You might be someone with staying power to see things through, who completes cycles naturally, whose growth energy serves manifestation. If undefined, completion comes in waves or you learn about finishing from others. The shadow appears when growth becomes endless expansion without integration, when you finish things compulsively even when they should be released, or when completion pressure makes you unable to start new things. The gift is mature completion—your capacity to grow things to fullness actually serves life cycles. You know when something is truly complete versus when it needs more time. Practically, this gate often manifests as being the person who finishes what others start, whose completion energy helps groups achieve goals, or finding satisfaction in bringing things to maturity.

sections.Image: The lake has risen up to heaven: breakthrough. The superior one distributes riches downward and refrains from resting on their virtue.
sections.Line 1: Mighty in the forward-striding toes. If one goes and is not equal to the task, one makes a mistake. Insight acted on prematurely.
sections.Line 2: A cry of alarm. Arms at evening and at night. Fear nothing. Insight bringing vigilance.
sections.Line 3: To be powerful in the cheekbones brings misfortune. Insight creating rigidity.
sections.Line 4: There is no skin on their thighs, and walking comes hard. Insight struggling to manifest.
sections.Line 5: In dealing with weeds, firm resolution is necessary. Insight cutting through confusion.
sections.Line 6: No cry. In the end misfortune comes. Insight unshared.
sections.Judgment: Breakthrough. One must resolutely make the matter known at the court of the king. It must be announced truthfully. Danger. It is necessary to notify one's own city.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 43 in the Ajna Center represents breakthrough and insight—the mental capacity for sudden knowing, for individual awareness that breaks through collective patterns, for insights that arrive whole rather than built step by step. The classical hexagram emphasizes resolute breakthrough of the inferior by the superior. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to breakthrough knowing and individual insight. If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular capacity for sudden insights, for knowing that arrives complete. You might be someone who has breakthrough awarenesses, whose individual knowing sometimes conflicts with collective thinking, whose insights seem to come from nowhere. If undefined, insights come situationally or you access collective knowing more easily. The shadow appears when insight becomes arrogance about what you know, when individual knowing makes you deaf to others' perspectives, or when breakthrough thinking isolates you from community. The gift is genuine breakthrough—your insights actually serve evolution rather than just making you feel special. You can share individual knowing without demanding others follow. Practically, this gate often manifests as sudden awarenesses that shift your direction, insights that arrive fully formed, or finding that your individual knowing eventually proves valuable even when initially rejected.

sections.Image: Under heaven, wind: coming to meet. The prince proclaims commands to the four quarters of heaven.
sections.Line 1: It must be checked with a brake of bronze. Perseverance brings good fortune. Alertness requiring restraint.
sections.Line 2: There is a fish in the tank. No blame. Does not further guests. Alertness to what's contained.
sections.Line 3: There is no skin on their thighs, and walking comes hard. Alertness creating difficulty.
sections.Line 4: No fish in the tank. This leads to misfortune. Alertness to absence.
sections.Line 5: A melon covered with willow leaves. Hidden lines. Alertness to hidden truth.
sections.Line 6: Comes to meet with their horns. Humiliation. No blame. Alertness confronting directly.
sections.Judgment: Coming to meet. The maiden is powerful. One should not marry such a maiden.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 44 in the Spleen Center represents alertness—the instinctual capacity to recognize patterns from the past, to see what's coming based on what came before, to be alert to truth through memory. The classical hexagram warns about meeting what's approaching with awareness. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent instinctual alertness to patterns. If this gate is defined in your Spleen, there's regular intuitive capacity for pattern recognition, for seeing what's coming, for alertness to truth based on past experience. You might be someone who knows when patterns are repeating, whose alertness serves survival, who can sense what's approaching. If undefined, pattern recognition is more intellectual or learned from others. The shadow appears when alertness becomes paranoia, when every present moment is interpreted only through past patterns, or when memory makes you unable to see what's genuinely new. The gift is wise alertness—your capacity to recognize patterns actually helps avoid repeating harmful cycles while remaining open to genuine novelty. Practically, this gate often manifests as sensing when something is 'off,' recognizing patterns others miss, or finding that your alertness to truth serves groups.

sections.Image: Over the earth, the lake: gathering together. The superior one renews their weapons to meet the unforeseen.
sections.Line 1: If you are sincere, but not to the end, there will sometimes be confusion, sometimes gathering together. Gathering requiring full commitment.
sections.Line 2: Letting oneself be drawn brings good fortune and remains blameless. Gathering through attraction.
sections.Line 3: Gathering together amid sighs. Nothing that would further. Going is without blame. Gathering in difficulty.
sections.Line 4: Great good fortune. No blame. Gathering succeeding fully.
sections.Line 5: If in gathering together one has position, this brings no blame. Gathering with authority.
sections.Line 6: Lamenting and sighing, floods of tears. No blame. Gathering in sorrow.
sections.Judgment: Gathering together. Success. The king approaches his temple. It furthers one to see the great person. This brings success. Perseverance furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 45 in the Throat Center represents the gatherer—the capacity to bring people together through your voice, to express in ways that create assembly, to educate or rule through articulation. The classical hexagram emphasizes gathering around a center. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent energy for gathering people through expression. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular capacity for bringing people together, for expressing in ways that create community, for teaching or leading through voice. You might be someone around whom people naturally gather, whose words create assembly, who has kingship or educator energy. If undefined, gathering happens through other means or you join gatherings rather than creating them. The shadow appears when gathering becomes control through assembly, when you need to be the center of attention, or when your capacity to gather makes you responsible for everyone who shows up. The gift is generative gathering—your expression actually creates beneficial assembly. You know how to gather people in ways that serve collective purpose. Practically, this gate often manifests as naturally drawing people together, capacity to address groups effectively, or finding that your voice creates community.

sections.Image: Within the earth, wood grows: pushing upward. The superior one of devoted character heaps up small things to achieve high and great.
sections.Line 1: Pushing upward that meets with confidence brings great good fortune. Determination beginning with support.
sections.Line 2: If one is sincere, it furthers one to bring even a small offering. No blame. Determination with modest means.
sections.Line 3: One pushes upward into an empty city. Determination meeting no resistance.
sections.Line 4: The king offers them Mount Chi. Good fortune. No blame. Determination recognized.
sections.Line 5: Perseverance brings good fortune. One pushes upward by steps. Determination proceeding gradually.
sections.Line 6: Pushing upward in darkness. It furthers one to be unremittingly persevering. Determination in uncertainty.
sections.Judgment: Pushing upward has supreme success. One must see the great person. Fear not. Departure toward the south brings good fortune.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 46 in the G Center represents determination—the capacity to push upward through accumulated small efforts, to love your body enough to care for it, to experience serendipity when determination meets right timing. The classical hexagram shows wood growing within earth, gradual ascent. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent energy for determined growth and self-love. If this gate is defined in your G Center, there's regular capacity for determined effort, for loving your body, for pushing upward through patient accumulation. You might be someone with remarkable determination, who respects embodiment, whose serendipity comes from sustained effort meeting opportunity. If undefined, determination comes in waves or you learn about embodied persistence from others. The shadow appears when determination becomes forcing yourself forward without rest, when body-love becomes narcissism, or when pushing upward means you never rest in what you've achieved. The gift is patient determination—your capacity to push upward through small accumulated efforts actually creates the conditions for breakthrough. You know that true ascent happens gradually. Practically, this gate often manifests as sustained effort that eventually pays off, deep care for your physical body, or finding that luck comes to those who keep showing up.

sections.Image: There is no water in the lake: oppression. The superior one stakes their life on following their will.
sections.Line 1: One sits oppressed under a bare tree and strays into a gloomy valley. Realization blocked.
sections.Line 2: One is oppressed while at meat and drink. The person with the scarlet knee bands is just coming. Realization during comfort.
sections.Line 3: A person permits themselves to be oppressed by stone. They lean on thorns and thistles. Realization through self-created difficulty.
sections.Line 4: Comes very quietly, oppressed in a golden carriage. Realization delayed by comfort.
sections.Line 5: Their nose and feet are cut off. Oppressed by the person with the purple knee bands. Realization through limitation.
sections.Line 6: Oppressed by creeping vines. In an insecure position. Realization finding unstable ground.
sections.Judgment: Oppression. Success. Perseverance. The great person brings about good fortune. No blame. When one has something to say, it is not believed.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 47 in the Ajna Center represents realization—the mental capacity to make sense of the abstract, to arrive at understanding through the pressure of confusion, to realize meaning that wasn't initially obvious. The classical hexagram addresses oppression and exhaustion as catalyst for transformation. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent mental pressure toward realization. If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular experience of mental pressure, of confusion seeking resolution, of the drive to make sense of the abstract. You might be someone who thinks about meaning constantly, who feels oppressed until understanding arrives, whose realizations come through sustained mental pressure. If undefined, sense-making is more spontaneous or learned from others. The shadow appears when pressure becomes constant mental oppression without relief, when you force meaning where there isn't any, or when realization becomes certainty that closes further inquiry. The gift is genuine realization—your capacity to work with abstract confusion actually produces insights that serve collective understanding. Practically, this gate often manifests as breakthrough understanding after periods of mental struggle, capacity to explain abstract concepts, or finding that your realizations help others make sense of complexity.

sections.Image: Water over wood: the well. The superior one encourages the people at their work and exhorts them to help one another.
sections.Line 1: One does not drink the mud of the well. No animals come to an old well. Depth not yet developed.
sections.Line 2: At the wellhole one shoots fishes. The jug is broken and leaks. Depth misapplied.
sections.Line 3: The well is cleaned, but no one drinks from it. Depth available but unused.
sections.Line 4: The well is being lined. No blame. Depth being maintained.
sections.Line 5: In the well there is a clear, cold spring from which one can drink. Depth producing pure resource.
sections.Line 6: One draws from the well without hindrance. It is dependable. Supreme good fortune. Depth fully serving.
sections.Judgment: The well. The town may be changed, but the well cannot be changed. It neither decreases nor increases. They come and go and draw from the well.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 48 in the Spleen Center represents depth—the instinctual capacity to go deep, to find solutions in the depths, to feel inadequacy that drives you to develop real expertise. The classical hexagram uses the well as metaphor for inexhaustible depth. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent instinctual drive toward depth and mastery. If this gate is defined in your Spleen, there's regular intuitive pressure to go deep, to develop genuine expertise, to feel inadequate until you truly know. You might be someone who cannot tolerate superficiality, whose depth serves others, who develops mastery through sustained attention. If undefined, depth comes situationally or you're comfortable with breadth rather than depth. The shadow appears when depth becomes perfectionism, when you feel perpetually inadequate no matter how much you know, or when going deep isolates you from practical application. The gift is genuine depth—your capacity to develop real expertise actually provides resources others can draw on. Like a well, your depth serves community. Practically, this gate often manifests as becoming expert in your areas of focus, feeling driven to truly understand rather than just know about, or finding that your depth helps solve complex problems.

sections.Image: Fire in the lake: revolution. The superior one sets the calendar in order and makes the seasons clear.
sections.Line 1: One is bound with the hide of a yellow cow. Revolution not yet timely.
sections.Line 2: When one's own day comes, one may create revolution. Starting brings good fortune. No blame. Revolution at right timing.
sections.Line 3: Starting brings misfortune. Perseverance brings danger. Revolution requiring caution.
sections.Line 4: Remorse disappears. People believe them. Changing the form of government brings good fortune. Revolution succeeding.
sections.Line 5: The great person changes like a tiger. Even before questioning, they are believed. Revolution complete.
sections.Line 6: The superior one changes like a panther. The inferior one molts in the face. Revolution transforming all levels.
sections.Judgment: Revolution. On your own day you are believed. Supreme success, furthering through perseverance. Remorse disappears.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 49 in the Solar Plexus Center represents revolution and principles—the emotional capacity to reject what doesn't serve life, to establish principles based on sensitivity to what's needed, to revolutionize when systems fail people. The classical hexagram addresses revolutionary change. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent emotional energy for principled rejection. If this gate is defined in your Solar Plexus, there's regular capacity for sensing when principles are violated, for revolutionary action when needed, for rejection that serves life. You might be someone highly sensitive to fairness, whose emotional clarity about principles drives change, who can reject what doesn't serve. If undefined, revolutionary energy comes in waves or you learn about principled rejection from others. The shadow appears when revolution becomes rejection of everything, when principles harden into rigidity, or when sensitivity to violation makes you perpetually outraged. The gift is principled revolution—your capacity to reject actually serves renewal. You know when systems need revolution versus when they need evolution. Practically, this gate often manifests as being sensitive to injustice, capacity to reject what's harmful even when difficult, or finding that your principles catalyze necessary change.

sections.Image: Fire over wood: the cauldron. The superior one consolidates their fate by making their position correct.
sections.Line 1: A ting with legs upturned. Furthers removal of stagnating stuff. Values clearing old patterns.
sections.Line 2: There is food in the ting. My comrades are envious. Values creating abundance.
sections.Line 3: The handle of the ting is altered. One is impeded in their way of life. Values temporarily blocked.
sections.Line 4: The legs of the ting are broken. The prince's meal is spilled. Values failing responsibility.
sections.Line 5: The ting has yellow handles, golden carrying rings. Values bringing recognition.
sections.Line 6: The ting has rings of jade. Great good fortune. Values perfected.
sections.Judgment: The cauldron. Supreme good fortune. Success.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 50 in the Spleen Center represents values—the instinctual knowing about what truly matters, about right responsibility and care, about nourishing what deserves nourishment. The classical hexagram uses the cauldron as metaphor for containing and transforming. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent instinctual knowing about values. If this gate is defined in your Spleen, there's regular intuitive clarity about what has value, about proper responsibility, about what deserves care. You might be someone with strong sense of values, who knows instinctually what's worth protecting, whose care serves life. If undefined, values are more situational or learned intellectually. The shadow appears when values become dogma you impose on others, when responsibility becomes controlling what everyone should value, or when care becomes codependence. The gift is clear values—your instinctual knowing about what matters actually helps communities clarify their own values. You can hold values strongly while respecting others' different values. Practically, this gate often manifests as being trusted as caretaker, clarity about what deserves resources, or finding that your values guide important decisions.

sections.Image: Thunder repeated: shock. The superior one in fear and trembling sets their life in order and examines themselves.
sections.Line 1: Shock comes—oh, oh! Then follow laughing words—ha, ha! Good fortune. Shock awakening to life.
sections.Line 2: Shock comes bringing danger. A hundred thousand times you lose your treasures. Shock causing loss.
sections.Line 3: Shock comes and makes one distraught. If shock spurs to action, one remains free of misfortune. Shock motivating action.
sections.Line 4: Shock is mired. Shock stuck in confusion.
sections.Line 5: Shock goes hither and thither. Danger. However, nothing at all is lost. Shock navigated carefully.
sections.Line 6: Shock brings ruin and terrified gazing around. Shock overwhelming.
sections.Judgment: Shock brings success. Shock comes—oh, oh! Laughing words—ha, ha! The shock terrifies for a hundred miles, and he does not let fall the sacrificial spoon and chalice.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 51 in the Heart/Ego Center represents shock—the ego's capacity to respond to the unexpected, to compete when aroused, to take initiative when life shocks you into action. The classical hexagram shows thunder doubled, emphasizing arousal and awakening. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent ego energy for responding to shock. If this gate is defined in your Heart/Ego, there's regular capacity for handling shock, for competitive response when provoked, for willpower that emerges through challenge. You might be someone who responds well under pressure, whose ego strengthens through shock, who has competitive spirit. If undefined, shock affects you more deeply or you learn about competitive response from others. The shadow appears when you seek shock to feel alive, when competition becomes your only mode, or when ego needs constant arousal to feel worthy. The gift is resilient response—your capacity to handle shock actually helps you and others move through unexpected challenges. You can compete without destroying. Practically, this gate often manifests as performing well under pressure, capacity to respond quickly to shocks, or finding that competition brings out your best.

sections.Image: Mountains standing close together: keeping still. The superior one does not permit their thoughts to go beyond their situation.
sections.Line 1: Keeping the toes still. No blame. Continued perseverance furthers. Stillness beginning in foundation.
sections.Line 2: Keeping the calves still. They cannot rescue the one they follow. Stillness unable to help others.
sections.Line 3: Keeping the hips still. Making the sacrum stiff. Stillness creating rigidity.
sections.Line 4: Keeping the trunk still. No blame. Stillness in center.
sections.Line 5: Keeping the jaws still. The words have order. Stillness in speech.
sections.Line 6: Noblehearted keeping still. Good fortune. Stillness complete.
sections.Judgment: Keeping still. Keeping their back still so that they no longer feel their body. They go into their courtyard and do not see their people. No blame.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 52 in the Root Center represents stillness—the pressure to be still, to concentrate, to meditate, to stop activity and just be. The classical hexagram shows mountain doubled, emphasizing stillness and stability. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure toward stillness and concentration. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular pressure to be still, to concentrate deeply, to meditate or practice focused inaction. You might be someone who needs regular stillness to function, whose depth comes from concentrated attention, who feels pressure to stop and be present. If undefined, stillness comes naturally or you're more comfortable with activity. The shadow appears when stillness becomes paralysis, when concentration becomes fixation, or when pressure to be still makes you unable to act when action is needed. The gift is concentrated presence—your capacity for stillness actually creates the ground for wise action. You know that doing comes from being. Practically, this gate often manifests as needing meditation or stillness practice, capacity for deep concentration, or finding that your stillness helps others settle.

sections.Image: On the mountain, a tree: development. The superior one abides in dignity and virtue, in order to improve the mores.
sections.Line 1: The wild goose gradually draws near the shore. The young son is in danger. There is talk. No blame. Beginning with caution.
sections.Line 2: The wild goose gradually draws near the cliff. Eating and drinking in peace and concord. Good fortune. Beginning finding stability.
sections.Line 3: The wild goose gradually draws near the plateau. The man goes forth and does not return. Beginning meeting obstruction.
sections.Line 4: The wild goose gradually draws near the tree. Perhaps it will find a flat branch. No blame. Beginning finding support.
sections.Line 5: The wild goose gradually draws near the summit. For three years the woman has no child. Beginning delayed.
sections.Line 6: The wild goose gradually draws near the clouds. Its feathers can be used for the sacred dance. Beginning reaching culmination.
sections.Judgment: Development. The maiden is given in marriage. Good fortune. Perseverance furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 53 in the Root Center represents beginnings—the pressure to start things, to begin cycles, to initiate development through gradual, orderly progress. The classical hexagram emphasizes gradual development like a tree growing on a mountain. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure to begin and develop. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular pressure to start things, to begin new phases, to initiate development. You might be someone who feels compelled to start cycles, whose pressure to begin helps things evolve, who initiates gradual development. If undefined, beginning pressure comes situationally or you're more comfortable continuing what others start. The shadow appears when you start things compulsively without completing them, when beginning pressure scatters your energy, or when you can't rest in what's already begun. The gift is purposeful initiation—your pressure to begin actually serves necessary evolution. You know which beginnings deserve energy. Practically, this gate often manifests as naturally starting new things, feeling restless when nothing new is beginning, or finding that your initiation helps groups evolve.

sections.Image: Thunder over the lake: the marrying maiden. The superior one understands the transitory in the light of the eternity of the end.
sections.Line 1: The marrying maiden as a concubine. A lame person who is able to tread. Ambition from humble position.
sections.Line 2: A one-eyed person who is able to see. Ambition with limitation.
sections.Line 3: The marrying maiden as a slave. She marries as a concubine. Ambition accepting lesser position.
sections.Line 4: The marrying maiden draws out the allotted time. A late marriage comes in due course. Ambition patient.
sections.Line 5: The sovereign I gave his daughter in marriage. Ambition honored.
sections.Line 6: The woman holds the basket, but there are no fruits in it. Ambition unfulfilled.
sections.Judgment: The marrying maiden. Undertakings bring misfortune. Nothing that would further.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 54 in the Root Center represents ambition—the pressure to transform your position, to marry into something better, to drive toward ascension through relationship or connection. The classical hexagram warns about improper ambition and relationships. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure around ambition and transformation. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular pressure to improve your position, to transform through connection, to be ambitious about where you're going. You might be someone driven to ascend, whose ambition seeks right relationships, who feels pressure to transform circumstances. If undefined, ambition comes in waves or you're more content with your current position. The shadow appears when ambition becomes using others for advancement, when you'll do anything to transform your position, or when drive to ascend makes you unable to appreciate where you are. The gift is right ambition—your drive to transform actually helps you and others rise together. You know that true ascension serves collective good. Practically, this gate often manifests as strategic about relationships and connections, drive to improve circumstances, or finding that ambition motivates sustained effort.

sections.Image: Both thunder and lightning come: abundance. The superior one decides lawsuits and carries out punishments.
sections.Line 1: When one meets their destined ruler, they can be together ten days and it is not a mistake. Spirit finding recognition.
sections.Line 2: The curtain is of such fullness that the polestars can be seen at noon. Spirit obscured.
sections.Line 3: The underbrush is of such abundance that the small stars can be seen at noon. Spirit limited.
sections.Line 4: The curtain is of such fullness that the polestars can be seen at noon. Spirit meeting guidance.
sections.Line 5: Lines are coming. Blessing and fame draw near. Good fortune. Spirit manifesting.
sections.Line 6: Their house is in a state of abundance. They screen off their family. Spirit isolated.
sections.Judgment: Abundance has success. The king attains abundance. Be not sad. Be like the sun at midday.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 55 in the Solar Plexus Center represents spirit and abundance—the emotional capacity to experience full range of moods, from melancholy to ecstasy, to know that abundance is an emotional state not just material. The classical hexagram emphasizes fullness and clarity. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to emotional depth and mood fluctuation. If this gate is defined in your Solar Plexus, there's regular experience of rich emotional life, of moods that shift, of melancholy and spirit both. You might be someone with deep emotional range, whose moods are information, whose capacity for feeling is profound. If undefined, emotions are more stable or you sample moods from others. The shadow appears when mood becomes identity, when melancholy becomes depression you can't escape, or when emotional abundance means you're never settled. The gift is emotional wisdom—your capacity to feel deeply actually helps you and others recognize that abundance is internal. You know moods pass and spirit remains. Practically, this gate often manifests as rich emotional life, capacity to be with intense feelings, or finding that your emotional depth serves others' understanding.

sections.Image: Fire on the mountain: the wanderer. The superior one is clear-minded and cautious in imposing penalties, and protracts no lawsuits.
sections.Line 1: If the wanderer busies themselves with trivial things, they draw down misfortune upon themselves. Stimulation scattered.
sections.Line 2: The wanderer comes to the inn. They have their property with them. Stimulation finding temporary home.
sections.Line 3: The wanderer's inn burns down. They lose the steadfastness of their young servant. Stimulation losing support.
sections.Line 4: The wanderer rests in a shelter. They obtain their property and an ax. Stimulation finding resources.
sections.Line 5: Shoots a pheasant. It drops with the first arrow. Stimulation precise.
sections.Line 6: The bird's nest burns up. The wanderer laughs at first, then must needs lament and weep. Stimulation complete cycle.
sections.Judgment: The wanderer. Success through smallness. Perseverance brings good fortune to the wanderer.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 56 in the Throat Center represents stimulation—the capacity to express stories that stimulate, to share experiences that capture attention, to wander through narrative in ways that entertain or distract. The classical hexagram addresses the wanderer who has no fixed home. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent energy for stimulating expression. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular capacity for storytelling, for expressing in stimulating ways, for capturing attention through narrative. You might be someone with gift for stories, whose expression stimulates others, who can distract when needed. If undefined, your expression is more direct or you learn about storytelling from others. The shadow appears when stimulation becomes entertainment without substance, when you distract from what needs facing, or when wandering through stories means you never settle into depth. The gift is purposeful stimulation—your stories actually serve understanding rather than just distracting. You know when to stimulate and when to be direct. Practically, this gate often manifests as natural storyteller, capacity to hold attention, or finding that your stories help others see things differently.

sections.Image: Winds following one upon the other: the gentle. The superior one spreads their commands abroad and carries out their undertakings.
sections.Line 1: In advancing and in retreating, the perseverance of a warrior furthers. Intuition requiring courage.
sections.Line 2: Penetration under the bed. Priests and magicians are used in confusing number. Intuition seeking clarity.
sections.Line 3: Repeated penetration. Humiliation. Intuition forcing rather than allowing.
sections.Line 4: Remorse vanishes. During the hunt three kinds of game are caught. Intuition manifesting abundance.
sections.Line 5: Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse vanishes. Intuition sustained brings clarity.
sections.Line 6: Penetration under the bed. One loses one's possessions and one's ax. Intuition lost in confusion.
sections.Judgment: The gentle. Success through what is small. It furthers one to have somewhere to go. It furthers one to see the great person.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 57 in the Spleen Center represents intuitive clarity—the capacity for penetrating intuitive hits in the present moment, for gentle but persistent knowing that cuts through confusion, for instinctual clarity that arrives whole. The classical hexagram shows wind doubled, emphasizing gentle but persistent penetration. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to intuitive clarity. If this gate is defined in your Spleen, there's regular intuitive knowing, present-moment awareness that arrives as clear hits. You might be someone with strong intuition, whose knowing is immediate and clear, whose gentle persistence eventually penetrates resistance. If undefined, intuition comes situationally or you access knowing through other means. The shadow appears when intuition becomes anxiety pretending to be knowing, when you override intuitive hits with mental reasoning, or when present-moment clarity makes you unable to plan ahead. The gift is reliable intuition—your capacity for clear knowing in the now actually helps you and others navigate uncertainty. You trust the hits that come. Practically, this gate often manifests as spontaneous knowing about what's healthy or not, intuitive clarity that guides decisions, or finding that your hunches prove accurate.

sections.Image: Lakes resting one on the other: the joyous. The superior one joins with friends for discussion and practice.
sections.Line 1: Contented joyousness. Good fortune. Vitality naturally expressed.
sections.Line 2: Sincere joyousness. Good fortune. Remorse disappears. Vitality from authentic source.
sections.Line 3: Coming joyousness. Misfortune. Vitality seeking external stimulation.
sections.Line 4: Joyousness that is weighed is not at peace. Vitality considering options.
sections.Line 5: Sincerity toward disintegrating influences is dangerous. Vitality meeting decay.
sections.Line 6: Seductive joyousness. Vitality as seduction.
sections.Judgment: The joyous. Success. Perseverance is favorable.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 58 in the Root Center represents vitality—the pressure to be alive, to experience joy, to correct what blocks aliveness, to maintain life force through engagement with what truly enlivens. The classical hexagram shows lake doubled, emphasizing joyous connection. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure toward vitality and aliveness. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular pressure to be vital, to experience joy, to correct what's deadening. You might be someone who feels driven to stay alive and engaged, whose vitality requires stimulation, who corrects systems that block life force. If undefined, vitality comes naturally or you're less pressured about aliveness. The shadow appears when vitality becomes addiction to stimulation, when you need constant excitement to feel alive, or when correction of what's dead becomes destruction rather than renewal. The gift is sustained vitality—your pressure to be alive actually helps you and others stay engaged with what matters. You know what truly enlivens. Practically, this gate often manifests as high life force energy, capacity to stay engaged long-term, or finding that your vitality helps others reconnect with their own aliveness.

sections.Image: The wind drives over the water: dispersion. The ancient kings sacrificed to the Lord and built temples.
sections.Line 1: They bring help with the strength of a horse. Good fortune. Intimacy supported.
sections.Line 2: At the dissolution they hurry to that which supports them. Intimacy seeking foundation.
sections.Line 3: Dispersion of the person's ego. No remorse. Intimacy through ego dissolution.
sections.Line 4: Dispersion of groups. Supreme good fortune. Intimacy beyond tribal limits.
sections.Line 5: Dispersing sweat, great cries. Dispersion! A king abides without blame. Intimacy in leadership.
sections.Line 6: Dispersion of blood. Departing, keeping at a distance, going out. Intimacy with boundaries.
sections.Judgment: Dispersion. Success. The king approaches their temple. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 59 in the Sacral Center represents intimacy—the sacral energy to disperse walls and open to intimate connection, to break down barriers through sexuality or emotional vulnerability, to generate intimacy through openness. The classical hexagram addresses dissolution of obstacles. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent sacral energy for intimacy and dispersion. If this gate is defined in your Sacral, there's regular life force available for intimate connection, for breaking down walls, for sexuality as intimacy. You might be someone with strong drive toward intimacy, whose openness creates connection, who can disperse obstacles to closeness. If undefined, intimacy comes in waves or you learn about sexual/emotional openness from others. The shadow appears when intimacy becomes sex without genuine connection, when you disperse all boundaries including necessary ones, or when openness becomes exposure that violates privacy. The gift is generative intimacy—your capacity to open actually creates genuine connection. You know that true intimacy requires dispersion of false walls while maintaining healthy boundaries. Practically, this gate often manifests as capacity for deep intimacy, comfort with vulnerability, or finding that your openness helps others open.

sections.Image: Water over lake: limitation. The superior one creates number and measure and examines the nature of virtue and correct conduct.
sections.Line 1: Not going out of the gate and the courtyard. No blame. Limitation self-imposed wisely.
sections.Line 2: Not going out of the gate and the courtyard brings misfortune. Limitation becoming prison.
sections.Line 3: One who knows no limitation will have cause to lament. Limitation ignored.
sections.Line 4: Contented limitation. Success. Limitation accepted creatively.
sections.Line 5: Sweet limitation brings good fortune. Going brings esteem. Limitation creating opportunity.
sections.Line 6: Galling limitation. Perseverance brings misfortune. Limitation too restrictive.
sections.Judgment: Limitation. Success. Galling limitation must not be persevered in.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 60 in the Root Center represents limitation—the pressure to accept constraints, to work within limitations creatively, to recognize that mutation often happens because of restriction not despite it. The classical hexagram addresses necessary limits. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent pressure around limitations and constraints. If this gate is defined in your Root, there's regular experience of limitation pressure, of constraints that require creative response. You might be someone who innovates within limits, who accepts necessary restrictions, whose pressure around constraints drives mutation. If undefined, limitations are more circumstantial or you're less pressured by restriction. The shadow appears when limitation becomes prison you can't escape, when you accept constraints that actually should be challenged, or when restriction makes you unable to see possibility. The gift is creative constraint—your capacity to work within limitations actually generates innovation. You know that boundaries often enable rather than prevent. Practically, this gate often manifests as finding creative solutions within constraints, accepting limitations without resentment, or discovering that restriction drives your best innovations.

sections.Image: Wind over lake: inner truth. The superior one discusses criminal cases in order to delay executions.
sections.Line 1: Being prepared brings good fortune. If there are secret designs, it is disquieting. Mystery requiring preparation.
sections.Line 2: A crane calling in the shade. Its young answers it. Mystery communicating.
sections.Line 3: One finds a comrade. Now one beats the drum, now one stops. Mystery in rhythm.
sections.Line 4: The moon nearly at the full. The team horse goes astray. No blame. Mystery approaching fullness.
sections.Line 5: Possesses truth, which links together. No blame. Mystery creating connection.
sections.Line 6: Cockcrow penetrating to heaven. Perseverance brings misfortune. Mystery proclaimed prematurely.
sections.Judgment: Inner truth. Pigs and fishes. Good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 61 in the Ajna Center represents mystery—the mental capacity to wonder, to know that you don't know, to be inspired by mystery rather than threatened by it, to access inner truth through openness to the unknown. The classical hexagram emphasizes sincere inner truth. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent access to wonder and mystery. If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular capacity for mystery thinking, for wonder, for knowing that inspires because it doesn't claim certainty. You might be someone comfortable with not knowing, whose questions open possibility, whose inner truth comes from mystery. If undefined, you seek more certainty or learn about wonder from others. The shadow appears when mystery becomes mystification that obscures truth, when you use 'mystery' to avoid finding answers, or when wonder becomes passive waiting for revelation. The gift is inspired inquiry—your capacity to wonder actually opens doors that certainty closes. You know that mystery is the ground of discovery. Practically, this gate often manifests as profound questions, comfort with uncertainty, or finding that your wonder helps others stay open to possibility.

sections.Image: Thunder on the mountain: preponderance of the small. The superior one is extraordinarily conscientious in conduct, extraordinarily thoughtful in grief, and extraordinarily economical in expenditure.
sections.Line 1: The bird meets with misfortune through flying. Detail creating vulnerability.
sections.Line 2: Passing by one's grandfather and meeting one's grandmother. Detail choosing appropriate focus.
sections.Line 3: If one is not extremely careful, somebody may come up from behind and strike them. Detail requiring vigilance.
sections.Line 4: No blame. One does not meet them, but passes by. Detail avoiding engagement.
sections.Line 5: Dense clouds, no rain from our western territory. Detail without manifestation.
sections.Line 6: Passes them by, not meeting them. The flying bird leaves them. Detail disconnecting.
sections.Judgment: Preponderance of the small. Success. Perseverance furthers. Small things may be done; great things should not be done.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 62 in the Throat Center represents detail—the capacity to express precise details, to articulate thoughts with accuracy, to notice and communicate what others miss through attention to the small. The classical hexagram emphasizes small things done well. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent capacity for detailed expression. If this gate is defined in your Throat, there's regular energy for expressing details, for precise articulation, for communicating specifics. You might be someone who notices details others miss, whose expression is precise, who can articulate thoughts with accuracy. If undefined, your expression is more general or you learn about precision from others. The shadow appears when detail becomes pedantry, when precision makes you unable to see the big picture, or when focus on small things means large things never happen. The gift is useful detail—your capacity to notice and express specifics actually serves understanding without losing sight of context. Practically, this gate often manifests as precise communication, attention to details in expression, or finding that your specificity helps others understand complexity.

sections.Image: Water over fire: after completion. The superior one takes thought of misfortune and arms themself against it in advance.
sections.Line 1: Drags their wheels. Gets their tail in the water. No blame. Doubt exercising caution.
sections.Line 2: The woman loses the curtain of her carriage. Do not run after it. Doubt accepting loss.
sections.Line 3: The Illustrious Ancestor disciplines the Devil's Country. After three years he conquers it. Doubt requiring sustained effort.
sections.Line 4: The finest clothes turn to rags. Be careful all day long. Doubt vigilant.
sections.Line 5: The neighbor in the east who slaughters an ox does not attain as much real happiness. Doubt questioning appearances.
sections.Line 6: Gets their head in the water. Danger. Doubt overwhelmed.
sections.Judgment: After completion. Success in small matters. Perseverance furthers. At the beginning good fortune, at the end disorder.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 63 in the Ajna Center represents doubt—the mental capacity to question, to doubt even what seems complete, to use logical questioning to test what's true, to remember past patterns as reason for skepticism. The classical hexagram warns that after completion comes the risk of disorder. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent mental energy for doubt and questioning. If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular capacity for healthy skepticism, for questioning what seems finished, for doubting until truly convinced. You might be someone who questions everything, whose doubt serves truth-finding, whose logical questioning prevents premature certainty. If undefined, you're more trusting or question situationally. The shadow appears when doubt becomes cynicism that believes nothing, when questioning prevents ever reaching conclusions, or when skepticism isolates you from connection. The gift is useful doubt—your capacity to question actually helps discover what's truly reliable. You know that doubt serves truth when held wisely. Practically, this gate often manifests as healthy skepticism, capacity to spot logical flaws, or finding that your questioning helps groups avoid mistakes.

sections.Image: Fire over water: before completion. The superior one is careful in the differentiation of things so that each finds its place.
sections.Line 1: Gets its tail in the water. Humiliating. Confusion rushing to completion.
sections.Line 2: Drags their wheels. Perseverance brings good fortune. Confusion exercising patience.
sections.Line 3: Before completion, attack brings misfortune. Confusion requiring waiting.
sections.Line 4: Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears. Confusion sustained brings clarity.
sections.Line 5: Perseverance brings good fortune. No remorse. Confusion transforming.
sections.Line 6: There is drinking of wine in genuine confidence. No blame. Confusion celebrating transition.
sections.Judgment: Before completion. Success. But if the little fox, after nearly completing the crossing, gets its tail in the water, there is nothing that would further.
sections.Interpretation: Gate 64 in the Ajna Center represents confusion—the mental state before completion, before clarity arrives, when imagination holds multiple possibilities simultaneously without forcing premature resolution. The classical hexagram addresses the moment before completion. In Human Design's reading, this becomes whether you have consistent experience of mental confusion and transition states. If this gate is defined in your Ajna, there's regular experience of confusion as transition, of holding multiple possibilities before clarity, of imagination that sees many futures. You might be someone comfortable with not-yet-knowing, whose confusion is creative rather than paralyzing, who can hold complexity before synthesis. If undefined, you seek clarity more quickly or experience confusion differently. The shadow appears when confusion becomes permanent fog, when you're so comfortable with possibilities that nothing ever completes, or when before-completion becomes avoidance of commitment. The gift is creative confusion—your capacity to dwell in not-yet-knowing actually allows better solutions to emerge than premature clarity would permit. You trust the transition state. Practically, this gate often manifests as comfort with ambiguity, capacity to hold multiple possibilities, or finding that your best insights come from dwelling in confusion rather than forcing clarity.

sections.gift: Natural innovation through being genuinely yourself. Your differentness isn't performed; it emerges from authentic desire and honest expression. You inspire others to be unique by modeling that individuality serves evolution.
sections.shadow: Rebellion for rebellion's sake, speaking without listening, forcing uniqueness rather than allowing authentic expression, or addiction to being an outsider.
sections.summary: Aquarian gates emphasize unique expression, mutation, speaking one's truth, emotional transformation, and the recognition of desires that fuel innovation. These gates ask: What new possibilities emerge when individuals dare to be different?
sections.archetypal_theme: This sign territory holds the gates of beginning the cycle (41), wanting (19), fellowship/listening (13), revolution/rejection (49), and recognition (30). Together they create an ecosystem of radical individuality—the courage to want something different, to speak about it, to potentially be rejected for it, and to ultimately be recognized for bringing innovation through authentic differentness.

sections.gift: Comfort with uncertainty and transition. You can hold space in the dissolving phase when forms are breaking down but new patterns haven't yet emerged. Your grace through crisis helps others trust the process of transformation.
sections.shadow: Drowning in emotion, losing boundaries entirely, spiritual bypassing, getting lost in the liminal without emerging, or addiction to crisis states.
sections.summary: Piscean gates explore emotional depth, family bonds, questioning before completion, grace in expression, and navigating crisis. These gates dissolve rigid boundaries and ask: How do we find meaning in uncertainty and transition?
sections.archetypal_theme: This territory contains gates of abundance/spirit (55), family/community (37), after completion (63), grace/openness (22), and darkening of the light/crisis (36). Together they map the dissolution phase—where boundaries soften, where what was complete begins to dissolve, where we learn grace in uncertainty, and where crisis becomes transition into new cycles.

sections.gift: Natural courage for new beginnings. You're willing to step into the unknown with innocent openness, can follow guidance even when it's uncomfortable, and grow through challenge without losing yourself in it.
sections.shadow: Recklessness disguised as courage, following without discernment, controlling through force, shock addiction, or growth without integration.
sections.summary: Aries gates embody innocence, following guidance, controlling resources, shock/arousal, and growth through completion. These gates ask: What begins when we courageously face the new and unknown?
sections.archetypal_theme: This sign holds gates of innocence/spirit of self (25), following (17), biting through/control (21), shock/arousal (51), and increase/growth (42). Together they create the initiation sequence—innocent willingness to begin, following inner guidance into the unknown, maintaining control through the challenge, experiencing the shock of the new, and completing the growth cycle.

sections.gift: Patience with the forming process. You can take innovative chaos and slowly, sustainably build it into lasting form. Your consistent nourishment of new things helps them survive the vulnerable early stages.
sections.shadow: Forcing form prematurely, over-nourishing to the point of smothering, getting stuck in renewal cycles without forward motion, or assimilating everything without discernment.
sections.summary: Taurus gates deal with ordering chaos, nourishment, returning/renewal, receptive direction, and assimilation/splitting apart. These gates ask: How do new ideas take sustainable material form?
sections.archetypal_theme: This territory holds gates of difficulty at the beginning (3), nourishment/caring (27), returning/renewal (24), receptive direction (2), and splitting apart/assimilation (23). Together they map the process of bringing new things into sustainable form—starting despite initial chaos, providing consistent nourishment, cycling through renewal, receiving direction about what's needed, and knowing what to keep versus what to release.

sections.gift: Natural bridge-building through communication. You can model authentically, stay present while connecting, express with contagious enthusiasm, and help diverse people gather around shared purpose.
sections.shadow: Performing contribution rather than authentic modeling, scattered presence without depth, skill without substance, progress addiction, or gathering without discernment about who belongs.
sections.summary: Gemini gates emphasize contribution through modeling, the now/presence, skill/enthusiasm, progress through experience, and gathering together. These gates ask: How do we share what we know and create community?
sections.archetypal_theme: This sign contains gates of contribution (8), contemplation/the now (20), enthusiasm/skill (16), progress (35), and gathering together (45). Together they create the communication ecosystem—contributing your unique voice, being present in the moment, skillfully expressing with enthusiasm, progressing through shared experience, and gathering community around what matters.

sections.gift: Wise protector energy. You know when to create safe pauses, can hold extremes with modesty, offer stillness when systems are overwhelmed, and support gradual development without forcing premature exposure.
sections.shadow: Over-protection that prevents growth, extreme mood swings masked as sensitivity, stillness that becomes stuck, provocative testing that damages rather than strengthens, or slow development that's actually avoidance.
